question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yoo encouraged pair shares where students were allowed to talk with their partners about discussion questions. We also conducted larger group discussions and had access to an interactive running document to keep notes. Students got an opportunity to present an introduction to the pre-work for the day. We also got pre readings and videos like excerpts to books and PBS documentaries. I liked how we had the option to write or send in questions beforehand, and I also like how we were able to talk in smaller groups before sharing to the whole class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great course to take for T-Reqs, I learned a lot about not just Asian American history, but why Asian American as a term exists in the first place--it's a term that homogenizes Asians, and yet it's a ubiquitous term because of how similar and interconnected the histories of immigration to the US from each Asian country and the experience of Asian American immigrants are. Very insightful course.

Second, I was able to develop a critical understanding of violence in the context of de-colonization and the limitations of nation-states. Third, the instructor provides diverse interaction with other urgent political issues and events, enabling us to think beyond the scope of our reading materials.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was introduced to so many female artists but what I really enjoyed was learning about their faults. They are complex beings and as exceptional as they were they also were flawed in the same way that we celebrate male artists who are extremely problematic (Picasso…) so this was a great introduction to what women are capable of in the art world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned a lot about women in visual arts and their different roles as artists, patrons, collectors, etc.; different challenges they faced; how they have been represented historically; how traditionally gendered analyses have influenced popular narratives; and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned a lot about women artists, the contexts in which they operated, how to conduct visual analysis, and how to question existing art historical practices of telling women’s stories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Visually analyzing art created by female artists, creating an art exhibit and understand museum layout, and speaking about how spotlight female artists

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I better understand now how to view art and appreciate it. I also know how to consider the history of the art when I look at it. I also better understand women's place in art history and how they were overlooked and what discrimination they faced.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about individual women artists, obstacles that they have faced throughout art history and ways in which they have met these challenges, and issues in art historical and museum practice regarding representation and treatment of women artists. The course explored many different ways in which women were involved in the visual arts in the early modern period: women as makers of art, women as patrons and collectors of art, and representations of women in the visual arts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the readings each week– they were well-organized thematically and provided a variety of angles and perspectives on each week's topic. It was interesting to compare/contrast them in our reading responses and discussion questions. The classes in the Nasher, Rubinstein Library, and Duke Gardens were a wonderful addition (especially the Rubinstein Library– I loved being able to engage with primary sources that were right in front of us!). Professor Hogan was always kind, understanding, and approachable and wanted her students to be comfortable and included in class, which resulted in a great learning environment. I also just want to say that this was a wonderful idea for a course and I hope that it is routinely offered in the future so that many more students can learn about this interesting and valuable topic!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will learn to think about art differently after this course. I can never go to a museum again and not observe the lack of female representation from this time period! There is certainly a lot of reading and analysis work, but it is overall incredible.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was a super interesting course– I learned a lot about a topic that strongly interested me, and it got me thinking about important issues of representation and equity in the art world (but also in general). The students had a mix of experience with art history and/or seminar classes—some were art history majors, others were just trying to get their ALP code, and others were somewhere in between—and everyone seemed to get a lot out of the class, which was great.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to analyze games, digital play, and interactive films through various theoretical approaches, including new materialism, agency, and affect theory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed several valuable ways of thinking and analysis. First, I was introduced to foundational game theories that helped me understand how systems of rules, play, and interaction can be used to critique and reimagine social dynamics. Second, I strengthened my analytical mindset by learning to draw connections between diverse readings, case studies, and media, bringing together theory and practice in meaningful ways during discussion. Finally, I began to see technology not just as a tool but as a medium that shapes how we understand identity and selfhood, especially through immersive experiences like games, virtual realities, and interactive media.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor allowed time for us to actively play and experience games and interactive films and to reflect on. Presentations were also assigned, giving everyone a chance to share their insights and engage with others’ perspectives.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated how the instructors consistently pushed us to explore different possibilities and brought new perspectives into each discussion. Even during times when I didn’t have much to contribute, I always came away with a lot of food for thought. Their approach created a learning environment that felt open, exploratory, and intellectually generous, which is something I would definitely keep for future iterations of the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course has provided me with valuable insights and skills. Firstly, I gained a deeper understanding of the overlooked social issues related to computer science, including their impact on marginalized communities. Secondly, I developed critical thinking skills to analyze how technology shapes and is shaped by societal values and power dynamics. Lastly, the course improved my ability to engage in discussions about ethical challenges in technology, fostering a more nuanced perspective on the role of computer science in addressing social problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of history about racial bias in the computing. I also learned about how discrimination is prevalent today, and some methods to reduce it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
learned a lot about current events and history that I hadn't learned about related to racism and other forms of discrimination
learned the role that technology plays in persisting discrimination, how technology is good and bad, how the computer science environment is culpable in discrimination, and more
reflected on actions of myself and others and how we can all work to improve our behavior to decrease this discrimination

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
We covered a variety of topics linked to sociology and critical thought, but our main content focus was on how Computer Science (as a field, as an industry, as a discipline) interacted with these systems of oppression - and how we, as future Computer Scientists and Sociologists, could (would need to) fight against oppression with knowledge and intent.(Some axes of oppression we touched on: ableism, misogyny, racism, transphobia, misogynoir, xenophobia/imperialism, classism.)
(Some CS issues we discussed: AI/FR technology, medical/legal algorithms, surveillance tech.)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Examining systems of oppression, connecting socio-political systems to technology, thinking critically about the social impacts and repercussions of technology

response_text: Unless serious changes are made to the curriculum to encourage more thoughtful debate and conversation, I would advise avoiding this class. These topics are very important to discuss, especially amongst a group of people (CS students) who don't typically interact with this kind of material or haven't in many years. That being said, from the onset it is very clear that if you disagree with the professor and the majority of the class, you're opinion is not welcomed. Rather than working to encourage people who haven't learned about this material to consider a different stance on it, you are outcasted and encouraged to drop the class, leading to there just being a bunch of poeple who have the same opinion as the professor. No critical thinking, and no debate.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This is the first course I have taken in Disability Studies and it was, needless to say, a fantastic introduction. Emily was an incredible professor whose knowledge, passion, humor, and enthusiasm made the class wonderful. I learned a lot throughout the course including the general models of disability, the ways in which capitalism and work intersect with disability, and the extent to which disability appears and is recognized, understood, perceived, etc. in society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me about different models and ways of viewing disability, such as the social model. We also learned about the history of disability and how capitalism has played into understandings and definitions of what it means to be disabled. Finally, we learned to think about disability in ways that allow us to apply these frameworks to other situations in the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
My view of disability and the idea of how bodies are a part of societal systems related to work (and the toll taken on bodies as value is extracted from them) was novel, and changed my worldview in a lot of things. 
1. Neoliberalism and how it puts a focus on individuals 
2. How external conditions can cause disability (like gangs) 
3. Cultural/shared disability was very interesting, especially when in the context of the Gaza conflict

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the different models of disability, I learned about disability in relation to capitalism, and I learned how to critically evaluate ethnographies, historical texts, narratives/creative works, etc in the context of our class

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned new ways of viewing the world and combatting bias.
1) The effect of racism and disease narratives on the world in the past and present.
2) The way disease has been used as a weapon.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the world around me and specifically understand drivers of conflict and violence through the lense of marginalized populations such as queer communities, women, those of different ethnicities and races, immigrants, and more. In addition, learning how to read dense texts, ethnographies, and articles was a big part of the course, and I learned how to digest, understand, and analyse these texts as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a deeper understanding of the history of racialized and gendered medicine. I also learned how to evaluate medical/scientific interventions from a racially-conscious perspective and learned how to read texts better. Many of the people in the class are interested in pursuing healthcare professions so I think this class is particularly relevant and useful for us to critically evaluate the healthcare system and the how medicine has advanced through the expense of marginalized groups.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I understood how historical context and biopolitics contribute to modern healthcare implementations for all groups who don't fit the standard cis, white, male body type. Along with this, I learned about who the actors vs. the subjects were in many cases, and how racism is inherent in many medical practices we pursue today. (For example, I honestly had NO idea that black women slaves were the unwilling subjects who gave us the practice of gynecology we have today.) I also learned how to digest large readings and get the main takeaways as we discussed them during class. As a cis white woman, I do want to mention how I came into this class not having a ton of background on these subjects and I now have learned so much that I will apply in the medical field - like taking into account the history of practices, understanding how livelihoods and backgrounds should be considered, and understanding how my own biases could impact my work on any individual.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to engage in seminar/discussion based learning. The class is also reading heavy (~150 pages a week), but it only met once so it was doable. I learned a lot about colonial legacies in healthcare

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained insight into the feasibility and ethical responsibilities in conducting ethnographic research/ the obligations you have when discussing a group's history, specifics about the creation of medical specialties and the system of public health in the US overall, and a troubling of the solutions I had previously devised for how to fix the US healthcare system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I genuinely think that this class pushed me on many fronts. It taught me how to do a class which such dense complex readings, it challenged me to think critically on my feet in class, and it kept me challenged but in a way that never felt un-welcomed / unhealthy.I really appreciated learning about different thinkers (which I apply both inside and outside of class now)-- and bringing this through the rest of the course. Seriously an amazing course... I was very nervous to take to at first but I haven't regretted it for a moment. This taught me also to follow my interests -- despite fears -- because it will be much more rewarding to learn about a topic you actually enjoy and to challenge yourself opposed to simply taking an easy-A class just for the transcript boost.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: (1) I learned various terms and concepts in Ethics, Philosophy, and Cultural Anthropology. (2) I developed theoretical frameworks which have changed the way I look at the world. (3) I learned about hope. First theoretically, then in terms of medicine, home, and crisis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Deep reading and analyzing of text. Being able to connect the various theories learned at the start of the class with new material learned. Thinking in a more ethical and philosophical mindset.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to compare and connect different texts from throughout the semester. I also developed my close reading skills. Finally, I learned how to take texts from authors and add my own interpretation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Anne Allison is fantastic. She is astoundingly brilliant on all fronts, has thought a lot about the topic of hope, and genuinely cares about what your thoughts are on the readings. Her reading-recaps are beyond helpful (she takes dense readings and makes them actually digestible), she is always able to answer questions, and she too applies the thinkers that we learned about early on in the semester on a daily basis. Professor Allison is a major component for why this class was so amazing and I think that she really went above and beyond to facilitate learning, engagement, and understanding in her class. Further, I think that she organized the class in a very intentional way. It was very smart to have thinkers first, then medicine, home, and finally disaster. She clearly thought about the structure of the course and every reading that we did / how it would weave together into conversations in class -- and I really commend her for how it played out throughout the semester. Professor Allison was also extremely available for help outside of class (I personally met with her a bunch) and she was overwhelmingly helpful each time. Finally, I really have appreciated the thought that goes into paper prompts because they prompt critical thinking that is engaging, intellectual, but also fun and enjoyable. Her and Anton did a great job with this -- serious kudos to them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Allison would guide the class through each reading. She would outline the general argument of a reading, draw connections to other readings, and emphasize the key takeaways. Some of the readings were more philosophical and dense, so I appreciated this method of instruction. Professor Allison was also incredibly encouraging. She was excited for us to participate, would help us articulate our points, and would refer back to our comments in later classes. I always felt heard and supported in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having the circle discussions and hearing all the unique insight Anton (TA), Professor Allison, and fellow students had to all the papers we read. The final discussion in replacement of the final essay was nice.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really loved the circle discussions, because it did not feel like a lecture at all. I also loved how we all would read the readings before class and come with our own individual interpretations before hearing what the professors thought or what my classmates thought.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I genuinely think that each piece was picked for a reason and I really enjoyed doing readings that pushed me out of my comfort zone and engaging in class.Talks were always engaging and Professor Allison always posed thought-provoking questions to the class which was always challenging, yet enjoyable.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I have never been a student who was good at close reading and analyzing texts for more complex meanings so it was a very different classroom experience for me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thought it was incredibly intellectually stimulating because of Dr. Allison’s breadth of experience. She also is a great orator and makes everything interesting. Regardless, the class material was already interesting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
- DO THE READINGS. I cannot stress this enough. 
- Try to really understand all the thinkers that you learn about in the first unit because they will all come up in conversation throughout the rest of the course and doing this would create a foundation to make the rest of the class easier.
- Just have fun with it! it is challenging but incredibly rewarding. You don't need to understand everything fully, just try your best
- Start your essays as early as possible - the prompts are long and really thought-provoking, which means leaving it to the last minute is not really possible
- Also meet with professor Allison outside of class! She really is the best!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Allison is an amazing teacher, and I strongly recommend this course. Weekly readings are interesting, and the two short papers were creative and engaging.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it if even mildly interested in any of the units covered in class or wanting to have a break from all STEM classes. Opens up new ways of thinking and discussing a very relevant/ever present concept of hope.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! Make sure to stay on top of readings- if you do it’s very interesting and manageable, but if you fall behind on readings, you get less out of class discussions and the work can pile up quickly.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Different perspectives on and approaches to ethnography, as well as the challenges of doing it (in the "field" and in writing).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was very helpful in learning more about a Black anthropological canon and methods. Three things I learned were: different kinds of applicable methods in the discipline, like mapping, embodied ethnography, and fiction writing; career paths for anthropology PhDs outside of academia and how these scholars write accessibly for different audiences; and finally, I was able to do a creative, non-traditional final project that helped me formulate my dissertation research interests.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Think of different ways that ethnography is both output and method and of different ethnographic methodologies.
How popular culture can be read ethnographically.
Connections with other academics are important to know and develop.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course invite me to expand my understanding of what it means to do ethnography, especially as it relates to Black ethnographers. I gained a good definition of what ethnography is as well as the varying modes and methods with which people use to engage ethnography, including visual, digital, and performance aspects. As such, I'm thinking more about the modes and methods I engage with as it relates to my doctoral project. I also developed skills as it relates to engaging with and creating connections across materials.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learnt why intellectual biographies are important aspects of understanding key anthropological networks. This is a learning strategy I implemented in all my other classes and will continue doing so in the future. 
2. I learnt the MANY different ways of ethnographic methodology - visual, ethnographic film, performance, poetry, essay, digital. All of which is very useful as a grad student currently engaged in ethnographic field methods.
3. I absolutely loved the syllabus of the class. The class flowed so well and the final paper for the class let us make the paper useful for us as scholars. I will keep in mind this syllabus when it is my time to create a syllabus too.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciate the different media we engaged with in the class! They were engaging and effective at communicating the breadth of ethnography.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Tracie is a caring and attentive teacher who creates a positive and warm space of learning and dialogue. I like that Tracie always includes a poem/song to start the class, and lets the class lead converastion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor always provided a list of questions from the readings for us to discuss. As well as putting up key quotes from the readings. A very interesting component of the class was to consider the intellectual biographies of the authors we were reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: It was great to be able to engage with the many writer and scholars we engage with throughout the course. It was helpful to see the different ways that scholars could address similar themes. I also like the use of articles and book chapters rather than reading entire books. I found it easier to get engaged with and follow the readings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The intellectual bios, using a multi-modal style of teaching ethnographic methods and the ways in which Professor Canada made the class safe to discuss our own positionalities with regard to our own anthropological careers was immensely valuable to me and certainly something I want to borrow for my own teaching career.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was fantastic! It's not lost on me how much Prof. Canada labored to care for us as a seminar, and invited us to do the same for one another. From the construction of the syllabus to getting feedback midway through the semester to the feedback you left on our submissions, thank you! These acts of care made it possible for us to rigorously engage with the material of the class, and our learning was all the better for it. I also appreciate that you'd tell us how you decided on the syllabus and how you were thinking about the course as a whole; super helpful for future educators!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating with a wide range of anthropologists working in different areas/on topics that often had similar theoretical concerns, but distinct methods or approaches. Unlike most grad classes, which are usually about the instructor's highly specialized knowledge, this class was helpful for introducing students to a broad range of thinkers and anthropologists...and for many anthropologists who might never learn about Black studies or Black feminist theory I think this is a great class to offer.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: A variety of approaches, objects of study and connections to content that was outside academia.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Canada really created a classroom environment where everyone felt willing to share as we wrestled with both the course materials as well as our own projects and positionality within the academy. Professor Canada was willing to welcome our questions and help us think through things we may be struggling with.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The fact that the readings for the class were so well-thought out and flowed so well from one week to another made the class very stimulating for me. Questions that would come up in one week would always be answered in the week later or in the following weeks which made the class feel very complete.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: 10/10, no notes! You'll learn so much from this course, even if your research isn't necessarily about race or planning to use ethnography. It's a deep dive into themes of doing research and being a career academic across many genres and flavors! Take the class!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great for grad students who want to learn about what the actual methods of ethnography are BEFORE you take the methods class! This has been helpful as I figure out how to describe my project and think about writing grants.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It may not look like it at first glance but this class is a lot of work between all the writing that is required the reading responses and the final. While the end of semester project is open ended, you will be required to draw a red thread to your own work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Black Ethnographers provides a great opportunity to engage with the work of Black scholars, writers, and cultural producers. While most of the scholars engage with were anthropologists, the class appeals to all students interested in thinking through what it means to write about Black life and how to engage in decolonial methodologies and theorizing. Additionally, Tracie Canada is a great professor. She creates a classroom environment that is fun and exciting. I looked forward to the class each week.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The syllabus of the class is exceptional - especially from a decolonial position. This class is theoretical and methodological at the same time and Professor Canada is willing to meet you wherever in your career you are at to facilitate your learning!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to become a better writer, reader, and to think about new topics from different perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Writing and reading skills, analysis, thinking about main ideas, confidence

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how to effectively write an argument and how to convey that argument in essays. Another thing that I learned is how to read a complicated text and take out the important things. Something else that I learned was how to talk about different texts and make complex opinions about each of them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Much better readings skills, picking a part texts to write specifically and academically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading/annotating academic articles, writing college-level essays, and thinking about how many aspects influence a certain subject.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We worked on developing our writing, reading, researching, and community building skills in this class, all of which drastically improved. We also specifically learned about healthcare history and the operations of labor and relationships within healthcare.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I feel like I took away more than just knowledge through this course; I learned to think deeper, constructively, in a bigger picture sense and also in a more detailed way. It was a great course to learn about hospitals, care, patient provider interactions and I was able to grasp a whole wide new understanding of the concept. 
- I learned the intricacies of care and the difficulty of receiving care
- how to read an intellectual, academic, hard piece
- how to write and read better

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my writing and reading skills and learned more about hospital labor.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my reading and writing skills, especially with more scholarly and research-based writings. I also learned a lot about me as a student and how I manage my time. Lastly, my analysis skills improved greatly, especially with being able to translate it into material that I can verbally articulate to a classroom.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
concepts in cultural anthropology: "double bind," the gaze, therapeutic geography
how to think across contexts (different time periods, different places): multiple case studies for each concept, differences in standards of care and availability of resources 
even writing and building arguments/ conducting research: final podcast project taught me a lot about conducting research and what questions to ask

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I completely changed my reading style throughout this course.  We had to tackle a lot of challenging texts, but I think the order in which we completed them made sense because we had to use the concepts as perspectives for future readings.  It was an interesting anthropological course, something I was not used to, we did not do a lot of field work and creating our own ethnographic work, nor did we solely read ethnographic material.  I did not expect this, but I have started to apply the tools we learned in this class on reading and discussing as well as the key concepts and developing ideas in other courses.  In summary, I learned how to go through readings differently and apply new perspectives for future readings as well as connect these to other readings with my own concept I create such as we did in the papers and finally talk through and relearn a reading in a way I did not originally do such as we did in Winart.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about proper ways to annotate reading, and how to read scholarly sources in general.  I also learned how to write an anthropology paper, I had never written a true college paper let alone anthropology paper so I learned the format of how to write that but also learned the differences between high school and college writing. I also learned so much through the course through discussion, we talked all the time and it was so helpful as it developed my understanding and knowledge of the reading but also the concepts within.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved having a specific syllabus with everything already planned at the beginning of the class. This was helpful for me in writing the essays because I was able to start early and write a paper that I could be proud of.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved how all of us were able to participate each class (disucssion-based rather than lecture). Instructor was very helpful and was willing to change the activity for the day based on the general consensus of the students. Structured but not too structured

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Solomon challenging us throughout class with difficult readings and topics helped to facilitate my learning because it made me think hard about everything we were learning and the different implications of it. I definitely think Professor Solomon should keep a lot of the syllabus the same because it helped me to improve my argument and reading comprehension skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: When authors came and talked to us about their texts that we read, this was so helpful and cool.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Sitting in a circle every class really facilitated discussion and learning and I didn't realize how much an affect it would have. The discussion based classes also forced everyone to stay engaged considering how small the class is.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was always very open for discussion, and every opinion was heard and encouraged. Reading articles individually and then discussing them until we came to shared understandings in class was a wonderful way to not only learn the "facts" of the readings themselves, but also what the readings revealed about the course's themes overall.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Solomon was proactive in making sure we each were engaged and thoughtful throughout the class and he tried his best to guide us in ways that he wanted us to get at in order to form deeper understandings of the pieces and the whole course in general.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: My instructor structured the course so that the topics flowed between each other. He used journal articles and books to convey information.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Solomon provided a lot of specific feedback and models that truly helped my skills improve without it just being "trial and error." He also taught a brief lesson on "skimming" a papre and although it was quick, it will be something that i carry with me throughout the rest of my academic years. Additionally, having required readings was tedious at times but certainly necessary and taught me a lot.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Solomon was organized and communicative, we at times had trouble reading through different texts just because they were so dense but he would then reschedule class time just dedicated to going through pieces line by line and discussing until we all understood the message. the current method of one reading for each session, followed by a small reflection and then class discussion was one that worked really well and felt natural while also teaching a lot-- also having all the readings files linked to Google Drive is helpful because it is easy to go back and have them in one place

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the circles of desks it allowed for easy conversations and discussions, and talking through the readings always helped the concepts to stick even more.  I enjoy the close reading and talking line by line even though it was very difficult in the moment I walked out feeling proud of myself.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is not a course about how hospitals actually work, it is a course about labor and how labor is performed in different circumstances.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think this is an awesome first year class. It I challenging but not work-load wise, thinking wise. It introduces skills that are critical throughout all college courses so it prepares you for everything to come. However, it does not overload work and there is no busy work so it's a good balance.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is not just for pre-meds or sociology majors - this class is a wonderful and interesting way to explore society, labor, and current events through many different lenses, while building very important academic skills. It is not difficult, and only requires a few out of class assignments. The majority of work is done via a very open discussion in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As long as you really take the time to understand and consume the readings and take each piece to your perspectives, you will take away a lot from this class!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class has only a few essays throughout the semester, but readings are due almost every class. Readings are graded based on three annotations which you do on the assigned reading. The annotations are pretty easy just 3-5 sentences per. The final assignment is a podcast which is pretty easy as well you work in groups and it takes a few hours to complete.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The readings are much longer and more complex and will take longer than expected. Purchase all of the books in the beginning of the year because the due dates sneak up on you and trying to get a book quickly is difficult in the middle of the year without spending a ridiculous amount of money.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read a lot, and know that you will not understand everything-- but you will learn so much: in addition to the concepts, you'll learn just how to read effectively and what to pull from articles and how to make sense of works within historical context. cool guest speaker opportunities, meaningful assignments. This class taught me more about how to be a better writer than w101 ever did. If you have any interest at all in healthcare then this class is worth taking, and the prof is extremely smart (can be initially hard to follow, but cares a lot about us understanding and always takes time to cool it down and explain)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There is a lot of reading, but they each have a different concept to take away.  The course builds on itself and in the moment you may struggle, but you are not alone.  The course changed me as a student and I am so proud of the differences I have made as a learner.  It is excellent as a shift from high school to college work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that the body and performance must be recognized as a vital source of knowledge production.I developed skills in thinking about and representing my research in different ways: drawing it out, writing about it in a stream-of-consciousness manner, activating a text I am working with through movement, and more.I adopted the thought process that endings are a social construct and sometimes the work comes to a temporary stopping point, but it is always developing whether you work on it or not. I feel more comfortable with the mentality that things will always be unfinished and I can always return to them when inspiration strikes again.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How the body has been ignored and forgotten in much of academic scholarship and how the written word has and still dominates what knowledge is valued (Spatz, Foster, Hartman)
How power is subverted and claimed in ways that the colonial gaze misses or misconstrues  (Mahmood, Taylor)
How scholars, artists, and ourselves are challenging notions of objective, rational fact as truth ~ bringing in creative writing, movement, performance and interdisciplinary thinking into our work

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The text activations were extremely effective in my engagement with each text. The first one we did felt like enough. If we had done two, I think it may have been too much.I was especially engaged with the text activation about the punching, slashing, floating, etc. that Professor Wilbur offered. It was an incredibly useful visual that I return to when thinking about my word choices and each position I take in a paper.I really appreciated the alteration of the classroom setup. It was mentally stimulating to sit in a new spot every day and it helped me get connected to other students in class.The accountability structure for the final project was well-timed for me. I grew more comfortable with sharing work in the development stages, which I feel made my paper stronger.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me develop several valuable skills and ways of thinking. First, the writing component challenged me to write concisely, choose my words intentionally, and extract the most important arguments from complex readings. It taught me to read more carefully and to use every sentence with purpose. Second, it pushed me to think critically about international institutions that claim to serve humanitarian goals but often operate in exploitative ways. Finally, the introduction to basic political theory at the start of the semester laid a strong foundation for understanding the more complex global issues we explored later in the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Namakkal created a strong learning environment overall. She is genuinely one of the most knowledgeable professors I’ve ever had—she seems to have deep insight into every part of the world. Her lectures were intellectually engaging, and she had a great ability to connect themes across time and space, which made the material more meaningful. However, the structure of the lectures was sometimes confusing. We had two lectures a week and one discussion, but many of the lectures felt more like unstructured conversations where students were asked to share personal opinions/views on topics. I often got lost in the material because I prefer more structured lectures where the professor speaks and explains key ideas clearly, followed by space for questions. The discussions should be the space for student participation, not the lectures. In fact, one of the most effective classes was when we had a guest speaker who delivered a full lecture without turning it into a discussion—I found that format much easier to follow and more informative.Professor Gasparowicz is a very sweet and kind professor, and she was also my discussion leader. However, her lectures were often difficult to follow. She seemed unprepared at times and made factual mistakes that Professor Namakkal had to correct. Her slides mostly consisted of long quotes that we had to read aloud and then discuss with a partner, which didn’t feel like real teaching. Unfortunately, I don’t remember much from her lectures, even though I believe she is knowledgeable. That said, she was more effective as a discussion leader, and I felt more engaged in our smaller discussion group than during her lectures. It honestly breaks my heart to write this and be a little harsh, because she is such a kind person—but I also have high expectations from Duke professors, and unfortunately, my expectations weren’t fulfilled in her lectures. In terms of grading, she was also the one evaluating my reading responses, and that was another area of difficulty. Her feedback was often vague and filled with grammar mistakes, which made it hard to understand what she actually wanted from me. Even by the end of the semester, I didn’t know what the grading criteria were and every new grade was a complete surprise. Comments like “explain” or “how?” weren’t helpful—especially for a freshman still learning how to write in college. With a strict 250-word limit, it’s hard to know what “explain” means when space is so limited. When I compared feedback with other students in different discussion groups, I noticed the grading was very inconsistent. It felt extremely subjective, which made the whole process more frustrating than helpful. Clearer rubrics and more objective, consistent grading across TAs would definitely improve the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
I loved how we looked past the surface level of many different topics. Like looking SAP in Jamaica, or developing an idea of modern day imperialism, and dismantling development theory, which many developed nations use to justify their actions. We were able to see past the arguments of politicians in power that use the surface level argument. 
Sometimes the guest speakers were a bit boring and not easy to keep up with. 
The reading responses were also hard to get a hang of. I would have appreciated an example of a good reading response from the beginning, I think it would have allowed me to do better on my first couple of reading responses. 
Although the midterm was a lot to study for, it definitely felt easier than the reading responses, as I generally like to explain a lot, so it is a good balance for people who may be used to writing a lot compared to the reading responses which were more difficult for me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course content was exceptionally well-curated, focusing on topics and readings that were both relevant and significant. One area that particularly stood out to me was the exploration of the rise of Western civilization and the socio-historical forces behind it. This topic prompted deep reflection and encouraged me to adopt a more deliberate and nuanced perspective. While I had previously considered these issues, engaging with this reading compelled me to approach topics with greater intentionality. I now find myself drawn towards conducting higher contextual examinations, delving not only into immediate considerations but also the deeper historical factors that shape contemporary events.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: There was a large amount of reading in this class, most of which were very information-heavy, densely worded, and abstract concepts that take a considerable amount of time to read, and even more to understand. That being said, I definitely learned how to read lengthy texts and vastly different narrative/literature styles more efficiently, which is a useful skill for all of my courses at Duke to come. I also learned how to think more critically about texts -- I might not have understood everything that was taught to the fullest extent, but critiquing it, I have learned, is a fundamental start towards understanding it. Lastly, learning how to write succinctly but powerfully was also a challenging and very valuable part of the course. Many of our writing assignments had hard word limits, which is difficult to implement when you're reading many of these philosophical-style texts that are so information-dense, but I definitely had to force myself to see which parts of my writing were necessary and which parts were not, and how to word/arrange their content more eloquently and succinctly.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to think critically about the global systems that are engrained in our everyday lives. I learned how to summarize and analyze texts concisely and connect themes throughout the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: ICS has taught me how to try and avoid having an Orientalist view on matters, how to write in a concise yet impactful way, and how to critically analyze global issues with cultural sensitivity and a broader perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that our Western mindset is extremely flawed and one-sided, and that it takes lots of work and knowledge to even grasp overcoming the biases we naturally hold. I learned that definitions of common words like Modernity or Globalization have many different meanings held by different individuals, and that no true "correct" definition can be established. I developed skills of skepticism and discussion about uncomfortable topics and about the unknown relationships in our world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Orientalism and its effects on the perception of "The Orient" by Western cultures. I also learned about the core-periphery model and how it functions by positioning the core (Western) countries in a state of political and economic power over the periphery (third-world) countries. Lastly, we learned about the clear overlap between colonialism and pollution, and how potential eco-conscious solutions can have devastating effects on indigenous groups.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I LOVED ICS195! Not only was the content extremely interesting, it was also intellectually engaging at all times because of the topics we covered are not often thought of as the mainstream ideologies people are exposed to in their everyday lives. Needless to say, I found myself questioning the most foundational beliefs I have held for most of my life and while it was disorienting at times, especially because of the unconventional dialogue we worked with, the support of the instructors at office hours, particularly Professor Mathers and Melissa Karp, made understanding, reconciling with, and applying those difficult conversations much more manageable and understandable. I significantly appreciate the instructors' willingness to challenge our thinking, and not just agree with everything we said, and their efforts in fostering constructive and critical conversations.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More participatory engagement during lecture classes would've helped students be more engaged. Oftentimes students have different learning styles and devoting an entire class time to talking and slides isn't the most engaging. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
As I said above, many of the arguments in the readings were cheap and not stimulating, it essentially was just explaining why imperialism and environmental damage are bad, and somehow the sole monopoly and fault of the West. Some of the readings were very stimulating, like Said's Orientalism for example, however these readings were just kind of tossed in with a bunch of other readings on other topics that in my view never came together as one cohesive unit. We would read Marx one week explaining what a commodity is and how it's harmful, and the next week would be reading about how climate change disproportionately affects countries in the periphery. It just felt very disjointed. 
The smaller group discussions were stimulating because I felt that's really where the only real discussions could take place. The main group class has a lot of kids which can feel intimidating or difficult to make contributions to, and as I mentioned earlier, the fact that the professor often just shut down students' ideas made this worse. Personally I am stimulated by making contributions to big groups and am not afraid of it and enjoy controversy, but I think the learning environment in the big class group was challenging for some to feel they could comfortably contribute.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It made us think of world problems in new perspectives.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Yes, the texts broadened my understanding. Also my instructor Courtney was really engaging and used a lot of examples to further help us understand the text. She would make connections in the texts that I had not thought of before and her personal accounts were instructing. By far one of the best TA's I've had and was extremely engaged with our class and each student. Aided in my writing skills as well and working to create texts that were concise but not just summarizing.

response_text: I think the content and readings were interesting, I just think lecture time could be used more efficiently. I also felt like the class was a bit disorganized – the syllabus and due dates were often confusing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class. While many are inclined to see ICS as a very niche humanities major (including myself, as an Environmental Science major), I cannot underscore how widely applicable this class is, both in professional fields and better understanding literally how everything within our society works. It can feel very abstract at times, but the content is based around theories and concepts that are so universally fundamental - like capitalism, colonialism, the origins of nationalism, accumulation of wealth - it would be extremely difficult to sit through ICS196 and feel like you haven't learned anything applicable. Also, I think you really learn the most when you go into classes like these assuming you don't know everything. If I had assumed all my preconceived notions were indefinitely correct, I would have felt like I did not learn anything, but being open to new, radical perspectives is essential. ICS195 was also not an easy class, both work load wise and intellectually, but the instructors always gave me support and direction when I needed it. I enjoyed ICS so much I'm considering double majoring in both ENVS and ICS.

response_text: There is a lot of information to process during this class. Make sure you really take the time to read and understand each week's course readings or you will be lost during exams and assignments. Also, assignments like reading responses are graded very strictly, so always put a lot of effort into them and don't be discouraged if your grades aren't what you expected at first. Look through the TA advice and follow their suggestions, and eventually you'll start getting better grades.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

In connection with the concepts we learned about some key thinkers and how to connect our learnings to current events. We also learned how to write very condensed and straight to the point analysis and comparative writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course helped me to view things from a more global perspective, and allowed me to introduce how these issues intersect.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me develop skills in assessing global inequities and relationships among nations. I also gained practice in concise and direct writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: core/periphery model, climate refugees, land vs Land

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: There was a large amount of reading in this class, most of which were very information-heavy, densely worded, and abstract concepts that take a considerable amount of time to read, and even more to understand. That being said, I definitely learned how to read lengthy texts and vastly different narrative/literature styles more efficiently, which is a useful skill for all of my courses at Duke to come. I also learned how to think more critically about texts -- I might not have understood everything that was taught to the fullest extent, but critiquing it, I have learned, is a fundamental start towards understanding it. Lastly, learning how to write succinctly but powerfully was also a challenging and very valuable part of the course. Many of our writing assignments had hard word limits, which is difficult to implement when you're reading many of these philosophical-style texts that are so information-dense, but I definitely had to force myself to see which parts of my writing were necessary and which parts were not, and how to word/arrange their content more eloquently and succinctly.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to think critically about the global systems that are engrained in our everyday lives. I learned how to summarize and analyze texts concisely and connect themes throughout the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Everything possible. Understanding the world and the theorists behind them has been incredibly stimulating.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I did not develop anything in this course. We did readings and writing, but I did not gain much.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: ICS has taught me how to try and avoid having an Orientalist view on matters, how to write in a concise yet impactful way, and how to critically analyze global issues with cultural sensitivity and a broader perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that our Western mindset is extremely flawed and one-sided, and that it takes lots of work and knowledge to even grasp overcoming the biases we naturally hold. I learned that definitions of common words like Modernity or Globalization have many different meanings held by different individuals, and that no true "correct" definition can be established. I developed skills of skepticism and discussion about uncomfortable topics and about the unknown relationships in our world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Orientalism and its effects on the perception of "The Orient" by Western cultures. I also learned about the core-periphery model and how it functions by positioning the core (Western) countries in a state of political and economic power over the periphery (third-world) countries. Lastly, we learned about the clear overlap between colonialism and pollution, and how potential eco-conscious solutions can have devastating effects on indigenous groups.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to write concisely
2. How to integrate arguments from texts with current events
3. The distinction between conventional definitions of terms and their actual definitions
