question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I LOVED ICS195! Not only was the content extremely interesting, it was also intellectually engaging at all times because of the topics we covered are not often thought of as the mainstream ideologies people are exposed to in their everyday lives. Needless to say, I found myself questioning the most foundational beliefs I have held for most of my life and while it was disorienting at times, especially because of the unconventional dialogue we worked with, the support of the instructors at office hours, particularly Professor Mathers and Melissa Karp, made understanding, reconciling with, and applying those difficult conversations much more manageable and understandable. I significantly appreciate the instructors' willingness to challenge our thinking, and not just agree with everything we said, and their efforts in fostering constructive and critical conversations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Mathers lectured us on Mondays/Wednesdays and my specific discussion leader Courtney Klashman led group discussions on Fridays. This layout works well with main ideas being broken down and explained within sections, also allowing questions to be asked and group work to be done. There were also group projects at the end of the course, which allowed for more discussions and collaboration on collective ideas.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would take it, especially if another professor is teaching it! It is enlightening. However, there is a bunch of busy work and writing activities that will question your actual knowledge on topics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There is a lot of information to process during this class. Make sure you really take the time to read and understand each week's course readings or you will be lost during exams and assignments. Also, assignments like reading responses are graded very strictly, so always put a lot of effort into them and don't be discouraged if your grades aren't what you expected at first. Look through the TA advice and follow their suggestions, and eventually you'll start getting better grades.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Unless you are pretty certain you are going to be an ICS major, I would recommend taking other political science courses to fulfill electives.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Pay attention un class and attend all the lectures.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to read text that push your understandings of the world and identify the global connections between colonialism and capitalism.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is okay, but I don't think it is particularly well taught. While the content is interesting, do not expect the instructor to be particularly strong. Some students found her slightly patronizing and she often went off on tangents.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed better skills for reading academic papers and writing analyses. I also developed a new way of looking at global issues as a more structural problem with historical roots.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. Through the reading responses, I've gotten a lot of practice in being concise with my writing. I tend to rumble, so it was very hard (and annoying) at first. But over time, I've gotten the hang of it and even grown to appreciate the skill.2. I've learnt a great deal of classic ideas in academia. Some I had heard of before but didn't understand, like Said's Orientalism, and some were completely new like Liboiron's Pollution is Colonialism. In all cases, the class provided very useful,  interesting and unique ways of understanding the world. Going beyond just understanding these classic ideas in the contexts they were written, the class provided multiple opportunities to apply and understand these ideas as they relate to the world today. The Reading responses and Op-Ed, for example, were great opportunities to link an academic concept to an issue we care about. I've learnt so much from my peers as well. I look forward to including more of Fanon and Cesaire's ideas in my anti-colonial discourse, Liboiron when discussing the environment and Orientalism when discussing Hollywood's next appropriating blockbuster.3. In thinking about the four essential questions of this course, I have thought a lot about myself and my placement in the globalising world. I have done many an internal deep dive about the ways in which my experiences have shaped the way I view the world. I've found myself asking what my personal relationship with capitalism and colonialism is, for example. I've thought a lot more deeply than usually do about Zambia where I'm from and how neoliberalism, for example, has permeated our society in interesting ways. What do I do that contributes to the climate crisis? What can I do differently? How do I hold others accountable? What do I care about? What am I committed to? This class has provided many opportunities for reflection, and I am better for it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the importance of colonialism in modern discrimination, the influence of capitalism on modern regimes of power, and how to read difficult texts fast.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) how does capitalism and neoliberalism structures the world we're living in
2) how to challenge a Western/White-centric way of thought 
3) what does it mean to decolonize

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really learned how to take better notes during lecture classes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how colonialism continues to shape global issues, how the white gaze constructs our understanding of race and development, and what role climate change plays in upholding inequality.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed critical ways to apply my teachings and relate them into my daily life with problems in today’s society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: ICS 195 challenged my ways of thinking, which the course was designed to do. I constantly found myself applying what I learned in the course to deconstruct my daily life. The reading response assignments were challenging by forcing me to be concise and truly choose the most important information in reading, making my reading and writing skills improve as a result.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I truly grasped the impact that this world is still under  from colonial powers. I better understood the extent to which the media portrayal of many unique countries of Africa with different beautiful cultures all generalized as one very stereotypical backwards nations that lives in huts and has no phones.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read large pieces of text, find the main idea, and concisely summarize it. I then used those ideas in class discussions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so many new ways of thinking that I never would have considered before. I learned so much about theory and history too. The readings were incredibly insightful. Three topics that stuck out to me were "L"and and "l"and, neoliberalism, and Cesare's Discourse on Colonialism. I thoroughly enjoyed this class and learned so much.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course was a great introductory course into challenging the way you engage with the world. We learned how to understand dense readings, interact texts with each other, and apply theories to the real world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course exposed me to perspectives that I had never gotten to consider before. It introduced to me important secondary and primary sources dealing with colonialism, climate change, capitalism, racism, neoliberalism, and how these interact with one another to impact people. It honed my ability to engage with new and unfamiliar lines of thought and to adjust or widen my perspectives in response. Finally, it helped me to be more intentional about my writing process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically engage with systems that influence our world and challenge preconceived beliefs about how the world works. I learned how to write in an efficient and to-the-point manor. I learned about the power of ideology in shaping what is "normal," and why it's important to question those beliefs. I also learned how to manage deadlines, as there are many different assignments that are due at varying times throughout the semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do the readings and try not to let them overwhelm you. Definitely ask for help if you don't understand what's going on. How much you understand is almost directly proportional to you utilizing office hours so definitely use them. The syllabus can be confusing sometimes so just ask if you don't understand something.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Go to office hours before you turn anything in, especially the reading responses – and make sure to go to the TA or professor who is grading your assignment. Don’t read every word of the readings; it will just confuse you with the reading responses. Just read enough to where you understand the main argument and sub arguments. If it’s a famous source, like Marx or Said, and you’re struggling to grasp the concepts, you can always look up an explanation or two on YouTube. But mainly, come with a curious mind, and you’ll get a lot out of this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come in with an open mind, seek the TAs at office hours (especially to perfect your reading responses), and don't let the deadlines get away from you.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: core/periphery model, climate refugees, land vs Land

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: There was a large amount of reading in this class, most of which were very information-heavy, densely worded, and abstract concepts that take a considerable amount of time to read, and even more to understand. That being said, I definitely learned how to read lengthy texts and vastly different narrative/literature styles more efficiently, which is a useful skill for all of my courses at Duke to come. I also learned how to think more critically about texts -- I might not have understood everything that was taught to the fullest extent, but critiquing it, I have learned, is a fundamental start towards understanding it. Lastly, learning how to write succinctly but powerfully was also a challenging and very valuable part of the course. Many of our writing assignments had hard word limits, which is difficult to implement when you're reading many of these philosophical-style texts that are so information-dense, but I definitely had to force myself to see which parts of my writing were necessary and which parts were not, and how to word/arrange their content more eloquently and succinctly.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to think critically about the global systems that are engrained in our everyday lives. I learned how to summarize and analyze texts concisely and connect themes throughout the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Everything possible. Understanding the world and the theorists behind them has been incredibly stimulating.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I did not develop anything in this course. We did readings and writing, but I did not gain much.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: ICS has taught me how to try and avoid having an Orientalist view on matters, how to write in a concise yet impactful way, and how to critically analyze global issues with cultural sensitivity and a broader perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that our Western mindset is extremely flawed and one-sided, and that it takes lots of work and knowledge to even grasp overcoming the biases we naturally hold. I learned that definitions of common words like Modernity or Globalization have many different meanings held by different individuals, and that no true "correct" definition can be established. I developed skills of skepticism and discussion about uncomfortable topics and about the unknown relationships in our world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Orientalism and its effects on the perception of "The Orient" by Western cultures. I also learned about the core-periphery model and how it functions by positioning the core (Western) countries in a state of political and economic power over the periphery (third-world) countries. Lastly, we learned about the clear overlap between colonialism and pollution, and how potential eco-conscious solutions can have devastating effects on indigenous groups.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

1. How to write concisely
2. How to integrate arguments from texts with current events
3. The distinction between conventional definitions of terms and their actual definitions

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I LOVED ICS195! Not only was the content extremely interesting, it was also intellectually engaging at all times because of the topics we covered are not often thought of as the mainstream ideologies people are exposed to in their everyday lives. Needless to say, I found myself questioning the most foundational beliefs I have held for most of my life and while it was disorienting at times, especially because of the unconventional dialogue we worked with, the support of the instructors at office hours, particularly Professor Mathers and Melissa Karp, made understanding, reconciling with, and applying those difficult conversations much more manageable and understandable. I significantly appreciate the instructors' willingness to challenge our thinking, and not just agree with everything we said, and their efforts in fostering constructive and critical conversations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Section was a great opportunity to ask questions and have discussions in smaller groups. I also like group work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the Friday small group discussions, allowed for a sense of belonging in a bigger class as well as a closer relationship with the specific designated TA.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor is quite interesting. She has unique perspectives but the lectures are not engaging and her instructions don't make sense.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Mathers allowed the students to control the narrative by encouraging questions about the topic, which led to fascinating discussions and deeper exploration of the subject matter. This approach created a dynamic and engaging learning environment where students felt empowered to contribute their perspectives.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Mathers lectured us on Mondays/Wednesdays and my specific discussion leader Courtney Klashman led group discussions on Fridays. This layout works well with main ideas being broken down and explained within sections, also allowing questions to be asked and group work to be done. There were also group projects at the end of the course, which allowed for more discussions and collaboration on collective ideas.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors had a large lecture component on Mondays and Wednesdays and a discussion segment on Fridays. The discussion classes did a good job at summarizing the lessons from that week and ensuring that the students understood important concepts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The most intellectually stimulating class I've ever taken! Very eye-opening, even more so because there was an element of controversiality and current relevance to everything we talked about. However, I do often find that our conversations and lectures left me discouraged (academically, politically, socially, about the world, etc.) sometimes, and I think focusing on these "unsolvable" issues that ICS is centered upon is evidently critical, but I would also enjoy learning more about current solutions and initiatives regarding these issues.

response_text: Having amazing TAs like Melissa, who was always willing to help and encourage students to actively engage, made the class much more stimulating. She motivated me to improve in areas like active participation, which I sometimes struggle with, and her support made a big difference in my confidence to speak up.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was actually extremely stimulating. I thought about terms and topics in new ways I've never done before, and I'm grateful for the lessons learned. The new topics and new perspectives presented during discussion made it stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More participatory engagement during lecture classes would've helped students be more engaged. Oftentimes students have different learning styles and devoting an entire class time to talking and slides isn't the most engaging. The discussion sections were much more stimulating, and aspects of the active participation activities done in this discussion could've made the class more stimulating had they been implemented in the big lecture classes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
As I said above, many of the arguments in the readings were cheap and not stimulating, it essentially was just explaining why imperialism and environmental damage are bad, and somehow the sole monopoly and fault of the West. Some of the readings were very stimulating, like Said's Orientalism for example, however these readings were just kind of tossed in with a bunch of other readings on other topics that in my view never came together as one cohesive unit. We would read Marx one week explaining what a commodity is and how it's harmful, and the next week would be reading about how climate change disproportionately affects countries in the periphery. It just felt very disjointed. 
The smaller group discussions were stimulating because I felt that's really where the only real discussions could take place. The main group class has a lot of kids which can feel intimidating or difficult to make contributions to, and as I mentioned earlier, the fact that the professor often just shut down students' ideas made this worse. Personally I am stimulated by making contributions to big groups and am not afraid of it and enjoy controversy, but I think the learning environment in the big class group was challenging for some to feel they could comfortably contribute.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It made us think of world problems in new perspectives.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Yes, the texts broadened my understanding. Also my instructor Courtney was really engaging and used a lot of examples to further help us understand the text. She would make connections in the texts that I had not thought of before and her personal accounts were instructing. By far one of the best TA's I've had and was extremely engaged with our class and each student. Aided in my writing skills as well and working to create texts that were concise but not just summarizing.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the content and readings were interesting, I just think lecture time could be used more efficiently. I also felt like the class was a bit disorganized – the syllabus and due dates were often confusing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great intro class to learn some basic ICS concepts and connections to current events.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: do the readings and take notes

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class. While many are inclined to see ICS as a very niche humanities major (including myself, as an Environmental Science major), I cannot underscore how widely applicable this class is, both in professional fields and better understanding literally how everything within our society works. It can feel very abstract at times, but the content is based around theories and concepts that are so universally fundamental - like capitalism, colonialism, the origins of nationalism, accumulation of wealth - it would be extremely difficult to sit through ICS196 and feel like you haven't learned anything applicable. Also, I think you really learn the most when you go into classes like these assuming you don't know everything. If I had assumed all my preconceived notions were indefinitely correct, I would have felt like I did not learn anything, but being open to new, radical perspectives is essential. ICS195 was also not an easy class, both work load wise and intellectually, but the instructors always gave me support and direction when I needed it. I enjoyed ICS so much I'm considering double majoring in both ENVS and ICS.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great course!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would take it, especially if another professor is teaching it! It is enlightening. However, there is a bunch of busy work and writing activities that will question your actual knowledge on topics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There is a lot of information to process during this class. Make sure you really take the time to read and understand each week's course readings or you will be lost during exams and assignments. Also, assignments like reading responses are graded very strictly, so always put a lot of effort into them and don't be discouraged if your grades aren't what you expected at first. Look through the TA advice and follow their suggestions, and eventually you'll start getting better grades.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Unless you are pretty certain you are going to be an ICS major, I would recommend taking other political science courses to fulfill electives.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to read text that push your understandings of the world and identify the global connections between colonialism and capitalism.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is okay, but I don't think it is particularly well taught. While the content is interesting, do not expect the instructor to be particularly strong. Some students found her slightly patronizing and she often went off on tangents.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about ICS core concepts like neoliberalism, world-systems analysis, climate change, Orientalism, colonization etc... In connection with the concepts we learned about some key thinkers and how to connect our learnings to current events. We also learned how to write very condensed and straight to the point analysis and comparative writing.

response_text:
Reading hard documents

Engaging with older texts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Applying multiple fields of study to one class, reading difficult texts, and writing with critical lenses

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course helped me to view things from a more global perspective, and allowed me to introduce how these issues intersect.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me develop skills in assessing global inequities and relationships among nations. I also gained practice in concise and direct writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: core/periphery model, climate refugees, land vs Land

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: There was a large amount of reading in this class, most of which were very information-heavy, densely worded, and abstract concepts that take a considerable amount of time to read, and even more to understand. That being said, I definitely learned how to read lengthy texts and vastly different narrative/literature styles more efficiently, which is a useful skill for all of my courses at Duke to come. I also learned how to think more critically about texts -- I might not have understood everything that was taught to the fullest extent, but critiquing it, I have learned, is a fundamental start towards understanding it. Lastly, learning how to write succinctly but powerfully was also a challenging and very valuable part of the course. Many of our writing assignments had hard word limits, which is difficult to implement when you're reading many of these philosophical-style texts that are so information-dense, but I definitely had to force myself to see which parts of my writing were necessary and which parts were not, and how to word/arrange their content more eloquently and succinctly.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to think critically about the global systems that are engrained in our everyday lives. I learned how to summarize and analyze texts concisely and connect themes throughout the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Everything possible. Understanding the world and the theorists behind them has been incredibly stimulating.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I did not develop anything in this course. We did readings and writing, but I did not gain much.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: ICS has taught me how to try and avoid having an Orientalist view on matters, how to write in a concise yet impactful way, and how to critically analyze global issues with cultural sensitivity and a broader perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that our Western mindset is extremely flawed and one-sided, and that it takes lots of work and knowledge to even grasp overcoming the biases we naturally hold. I learned that definitions of common words like Modernity or Globalization have many different meanings held by different individuals, and that no true "correct" definition can be established. I developed skills of skepticism and discussion about uncomfortable topics and about the unknown relationships in our world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Orientalism and its effects on the perception of "The Orient" by Western cultures. I also learned about the core-periphery model and how it functions by positioning the core (Western) countries in a state of political and economic power over the periphery (third-world) countries. Lastly, we learned about the clear overlap between colonialism and pollution, and how potential eco-conscious solutions can have devastating effects on indigenous groups.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to write concisely
2. How to integrate arguments from texts with current events
3. The distinction between conventional definitions of terms and their actual definitions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: reading responses, research on projects, and global perspectives.

response_text:

Some of the readings were very stimulating, like Said's Orientalism for example, however these readings were just kind of tossed in with a bunch of other readings on other topics that in my view never came together as one cohesive unit. We would read Marx one week explaining what a commodity is and how it's harmful, and the next week would be reading about how climate change disproportionately affects countries in the periphery. It just felt very disjointed. 
The smaller group discussions were stimulating because I felt that's really where the only real discussions could take place. The main group class has a lot of kids which can feel intimidating or difficult to make contributions to, and as I mentioned earlier, the fact that the professor often just shut down students' ideas made this worse. Personally I am stimulated by making contributions to big groups and am not afraid of it and enjoy controversy, but I think the learning environment in the big class group was challenging for some to feel they could comfortably contribute.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class. While many are inclined to see ICS as a very niche humanities major (including myself, as an Environmental Science major), I cannot underscore how widely applicable this class is, both in professional fields and better understanding literally how everything within our society works. It can feel very abstract at times, but the content is based around theories and concepts that are so universally fundamental - like capitalism, colonialism, the origins of nationalism, accumulation of wealth - it would be extremely difficult to sit through ICS196 and feel like you haven't learned anything applicable. Also, I think you really learn the most when you go into classes like these assuming you don't know everything. If I had assumed all my preconceived notions were indefinitely correct, I would have felt like I did not learn anything, but being open to new, radical perspectives is essential. ICS195 was also not an easy class, both work load wise and intellectually, but the instructors always gave me support and direction when I needed it. I enjoyed ICS so much I'm considering double majoring in both ENVS and ICS.

First, the writing component challenged me to write concisely, choose my words intentionally, and extract the most important arguments from complex readings. It taught me to read more carefully and to use every sentence with purpose. Finally, the introduction to basic political theory at the start of the semester laid a strong foundation for understanding the more complex global issues we explored later in the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Namakkal created a strong learning environment overall. She is genuinely one of the most knowledgeable professors I’ve ever had—she seems to have deep insight into every part of the world. Her lectures were intellectually engaging, and she had a great ability to connect themes across time and space, which made the material more meaningful. However, the structure of the lectures was sometimes confusing. We had two lectures a week and one discussion, but many of the lectures felt more like unstructured conversations where students were asked to share personal opinions/views on topics. I often got lost in the material because I prefer more structured lectures where the professor speaks and explains key ideas clearly, followed by space for questions. The discussions should be the space for student participation, not the lectures. In fact, one of the most effective classes was when we had a guest speaker who delivered a full lecture without turning it into a discussion—I found that format much easier to follow and more informative.Professor Gasparowicz is a very sweet and kind professor, and she was also my discussion leader. However, her lectures were often difficult to follow. She seemed unprepared at times and made factual mistakes that Professor Namakkal had to correct. Her slides mostly consisted of long quotes that we had to read aloud and then discuss with a partner, which didn’t feel like real teaching. Unfortunately, I don’t remember much from her lectures, even though I believe she is knowledgeable. That said, she was more effective as a discussion leader, and I felt more engaged in our smaller discussion group than during her lectures. It honestly breaks my heart to write this and be a little harsh, because she is such a kind person—but I also have high expectations from Duke professors, and unfortunately, my expectations weren’t fulfilled in her lectures. In terms of grading, she was also the one evaluating my reading responses, and that was another area of difficulty. Her feedback was often vague and filled with grammar mistakes, which made it hard to understand what she actually wanted from me. Even by the end of the semester, I didn’t know what the grading criteria were and every new grade was a complete surprise. Comments like “explain” or “how?” weren’t helpful—especially for a freshman still learning how to write in college. With a strict 250-word limit, it’s hard to know what “explain” means when space is so limited. When I compared feedback with other students in different discussion groups, I noticed the grading was very inconsistent. It felt extremely subjective, which made the whole process more frustrating than helpful. Clearer rubrics and more objective, consistent grading across TAs would definitely improve the course.

response_text: The readings were long and you didn't really have to do them for the reading responses. The in-class lectures were engaging but the whole semester I was thinking about everything that is happening in the real world yet we didn't address that at all. I recommend connecting readings/concepts to present day issues next time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It constantly related to current issues and emphasized the reverberations and interconnected nature of historical and contemporary fights for justice. It also challenged the ways we previously would learn about history and global politics in high school settings (eg in a very Eurocentric manner). As a student activist myself I really appreciated that this was a constant focus in the classroom.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
I loved how we looked past the surface level of many different topics. Like looking SAP in Jamaica, or developing an idea of modern day imperialism, and dismantling development theory, which many developed nations use to justify their actions. We were able to see past the arguments of politicians in power that use the surface level argument. 
Sometimes the guest speakers were a bit boring and not easy to keep up with. 
The reading responses were also hard to get a hang of. I would have appreciated an example of a good reading response from the beginning, I think it would have allowed me to do better on my first couple of reading responses. 
Although the midterm was a lot to study for, it definitely felt easier than the reading responses, as I generally like to explain a lot, so it is a good balance for people who may be used to writing a lot compared to the reading responses which were more difficult for me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were very interesting and covered a really wide range of topics. I do wish we spent more time discussing the Friday material as it often kinda got dismissed during discussion, and was very interesting. Some of my favorite readings include The state of South African political life by Mbembe, Planet of Slums by Davis, and Borderlands by Anzaldua.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The chosen topics were very stimulating as they gave multiple perspectives and were relevant to today's world. I really appreciated that the course worked to reveal a layer of complexity within each issue that is not obvious at first glance.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I would say the first half of the semester was very engaging, and included a lot of contemporary issues going on in the world. However, I noticed a trend towards the end that consistently continued to bring up a form of liberalism or colonialism. While these are deeply engaging topics, I felt as if the course is quite concentrated on these two issues, and was more about them than a breadth of what is going on in the world.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussions we had in class and the discussion section were very stimulating. I also enjoyed it when we got to talk to the person next to us and discuss things because it allowed me to understand their point of view and connect on some similar points.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Incorporation of current events as well as the hosting of professors from specific areas of expertise was super interesting. The syllabus was very flexible and the professors would sometimes modify readings depending on student interest which I appreciated, and kept the calss engaged.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved learning about student movements and what that means during this time here in the U.S. and throughout history. I also loved reading and discussing Fanon, Cesaire, colonialism and watching the documentary from this unit.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think bringing current events to the lesson would have made it the most useful to grounding our understanding of these impacts

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I liked most of the readings, particularly those in the second unit. I appreciated that if you disliked a unit it only lasted a week (except proletariat and bourgeoisie, that seemed to last forever and would recommend cutting back on how much you discuss that). I liked guest speakers who came in, it helped stimulate us as we got used to the class set up. I also appreciated the structure of the class. Nothing was a surprise (weekly reading responses, counter map, and 2 tests). The class could be more stimulating if we didn't just summarize readings in lecture, which it sometimes felt that's what we did. Readings could be significantly shorter.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: discussion in lectures and in sections

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course was intellectually stimulating mainly because of the writing assignments, which required us to read closely and distill complex texts into concise arguments. That process helped me develop critical thinking skills. However, the intense focus on colonialism made the course feel somewhat one-sided and repetitive. Including more diverse perspectives—both politically and topically—would have added depth and balance. Some students may find the political leaning of the course very liberal, and it might be difficult for those with different viewpoints to feel comfortable sharing their thoughts.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Content & teaching style were very stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was made stimulating through the questions that would be asked in class pertaining to the different topics we would cover and the weekly writings we did.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Interact in class! Even if it seems intimidating or it feels like you already know this stuff, the more I interacted the more I got out of this class. Especially if you are an ICS major, this is a great time to showcase your true interest in the subject and get the teaching team to remember who you are (ICS is a pretty small community). You can push for nuance in your discussions and it will be rewarded.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is extremely interesting and exciting. You learn really fascinating concepts through a different lens from a traditional history class. However, there are weekly writing assignments that are graded hard and push students to grow as critical writers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: For an intro course it's better than average, but it's not my favorite class. The reading responses are frustrating and the outside of class work takes an obscene amount of time for an intro class. The course content is relatively interesting and Namakaal is a really good lecturer. Take it for the major, take a higher level elective for an elective of interest in ICS.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is very different from what you might expect. If you're hoping to focus on current global issues, you may find the emphasis on colonialism throughout the semester limiting. The main component of the class is writing—especially the weekly reading responses—which can be challenging and is graded strictly. While the course is officially about global issues, in practice it felt more like a writing class with a cross-cultural inquiry tag. That said, it’s a valuable experience for improving your writing and learning to engage critically with texts. Just be prepared for the writing component to take center stage.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is hard for an intro course but take it anyways. One of the best classes I have taken at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned about some aspects of queer theory, how to engage with queer media thoughtfully, and how to better articulate my thoughts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about queer cinema and about the context in which the films we watched were created.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Developed ability to analyze film, engaged with content that strengthened queer theoretical background and gave me practice reading cinematographic queerness.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was exposed to a wide variety of popular queer media, most of which I had not seen yet and was grateful to have experienced now. I think I got much more accustomed to film theory and ideas, and writing critically about films, since I’d never taken a film centric class prior to this one.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze cinema using the lens of queer theory, how to create a zine, and how to write about movies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of new perspectives about queerness and how it is portrayed in media. I learned how to critically analyze LGBTQ media on my own, and through experiencing queer media learned a lot of queer history

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about a few different film techniques that can be used to generate various feelings for the viewer. I also learned about the history of expression and repression in queer media, particularly in the context of the Hays code. I also learned how different people define and express their identity, which I felt that the discord posts facilitated.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Different points to start on when analyzing a film. 
2. How to combine literature work into film analysis
3. Comparison between films

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Archer did a wonderful job facilitating fruitful discussions in class and on Discord. I liked the format -- having a discussion and then watching a film was a great way to proceed through the class and keep us interested.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed hearing about other people's opinions of the films during class discussions. The discord responses were a good way to reflect on the assigned films and readings. My favorite part of the course was probably the midterm (zine), which was really fun to make.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes, the structure of the course was fantastic. To split screenings and discussion both between class and home kept me engaged with the material throughout the week and fostered reflection. Discussions in class often left me with new insights and rarely dragged on for too long.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that discussion was very open, and that Professor Boyette encouraged us to explore alternative methods of thinking about film, such as making zines and creating our own film proposal, which I found much more interesting than just writing a midterm/final essay.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the Discord-hosted forum, for one because it felt like an actual discussion space due to it not being hosted on an academic site, and secondly because I loved hearing what my classmates were thinking about the movies we watched since we couldn’t discuss immediately after the showing. I also loved the midterm zine and this should definitely be kept!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
The content and critical thinking. The class discussions especially. 
Notes to improve the class:
I personally felt very self-conscious of what to say in class often. I was afraid of saying the wrong thing and being judged or canceled for it. I think the class can really benefit from frequent reminders to express oneself as long as we're intending to learn and we're driven by curiosity. The philosopher J. S. Mill says that the controversial statements and questions are those that get us closer to truth, make us improve our arguments, and prevent dead dogmas. So I really want this class to cultivate the courage for everyone to speak their mind more openly without worrying about consequences.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a good class, if English is not your native language (like me), you may find some of the reading difficult, and the amount of reading assigned is not small if you intend to give them more than just a skim through. The papers can be challenging at first, but they're decently easy to get the hang of. You will learn how things that looked "natural" or "familiar" (like gender expression, or bathrooms) are actually socially constructed and serves important functions such as helping uphold a social hierarchy. It is an eye opener, and you will start to notice things that you always see, but have never paid attention to.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Some skills and insights that I developed in this course include critical and analytical thinking, close readings of literature and film, and academic writing. 
1. In film, everything is intentional. While a major aspect of film is entertainment, films are attempt to "say" things. 
2. In order to get at what a film is trying to "say," pay attention to what's there (color, space, storytelling, dialogue, etc.) but, perhaps more importantly, note what is absent. 
3. Films converse between each other all the time.

response_text: I liked that we had an open discussion format. Both professors emphasized respect and open-mindedness, which made me more comfortable to share my thoughts/opinions, even if I felt they were underwhelming. Moreover, I like that this was a relatively small class as it allowed us all to bond in a way that would not have been possible with a bigger class, while maintaining fruitful discussion. Finally, arguably my favorite part about this course were the class speakers. I loved engaging with women leaders from various states and sectors of the public. I learned the most from them and their interviews.

I think this course not only furthered my knowledge on women in the political process, but helped me to better engage with the Duke and Durham community. I think everyone-- regardless of major, etc-- should take this course!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about different laws, policies, and the gender gape in the electorate process and the transitions of power over the years.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the multifaceted components of politics from different lens. I now understand how media representation is an important influence to how women in politics are perceived. I also learned about different notions of freedom and how it contributes to poltics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first class using Premiere Pro. I got an intro course on editing professional-looking videos and collaborating with other editors. Another thing I learned was the difference between campaigns backed by big money and grass roots campaigns. Lastly I learned about the barriers women face to get elected into office and what can be done to encourage more women to run and win.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that we had an open discussion format. Both professors emphasized respect and open-mindedness, which made me more comfortable to share my thoughts/opinions, even if I felt they were underwhelming. I also enjoyed that we made documentary-style episodes. I felt that I was able to express a creative side to myself that I am not usually able to do through my other Duke courses. Moreover, I like that this was a relatively small class as it allowed us all to bond in a way that would not have been possible with a bigger class, while maintaining fruitful discussion. Finally, arguably my favorite part about this course were the class speakers. I loved engaging with women leaders from various states and sectors of the public. I learned the most from them and their interviews.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Enriques was a truly a thought provoking and amazing teacher that really wanted to create the space for Hispanic students to have the option to speak about their issues, to connect, and collaborate. The class itself became a community in which we could talk about LGBTQ+, racism, prejudice, and our Latin identity. Professor Enriquez fully welcomed these thoughts and perspectives, allowing our voices to be heard and nurtured in a safe environment. She continued asking thought provoking questions to really understand our background and our place now. I would definitely keep the mesa redondas, discussion about the movies, and the zine.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This is the first course I have taken in Disability Studies and it was, needless to say, a fantastic introduction. Emily was an incredible professor whose knowledge, passion, humor, and enthusiasm made the class wonderful. I learned a lot throughout the course including the general models of disability, the ways in which capitalism and work intersect with disability, and the extent to which disability appears and is recognized, understood, perceived, etc. in society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class taught me about different models and ways of viewing disability, such as the social model. We also learned about the history of disability and how capitalism has played into understandings and definitions of what it means to be disabled. Finally, we learned to think about disability in ways that allow us to apply these frameworks to other situations in the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
My view of disability and the idea of how bodies are a part of societal systems related to work (and the toll taken on bodies as value is extracted from them) was novel, and changed my worldview in a lot of things. 
1. Neoliberalism and how it puts a focus on individuals 
2. How external conditions can cause disability (like gangs) 
3. Cultural/shared disability was very interesting, especially when in the context of the Gaza conflict

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the different models of disability, I learned about disability in relation to capitalism, and I learned how to critically evaluate ethnographies, historical texts, narratives/creative works, etc in the context of our class

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course has provided me with valuable insights and skills. Firstly, I gained a deeper understanding of the overlooked social issues related to computer science, including their impact on marginalized communities. Secondly, I developed critical thinking skills to analyze how technology shapes and is shaped by societal values and power dynamics. Lastly, the course improved my ability to engage in discussions about ethical challenges in technology, fostering a more nuanced perspective on the role of computer science in addressing social problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of history about racial bias in the computing. I also learned about how discrimination is prevalent today, and some methods to reduce it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
learned a lot about current events and history that I hadn't learned about related to racism and other forms of discrimination
learned the role that technology plays in persisting discrimination, how technology is good and bad, how the computer science environment is culpable in discrimination, and more
reflected on actions of myself and others and how we can all work to improve our behavior to decrease this discrimination

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
We covered a variety of topics linked to sociology and critical thought, but our main content focus was on how Computer Science (as a field, as an industry, as a discipline) interacted with these systems of oppression - and how we, as future Computer Scientists and Sociologists, could (would need to) fight against oppression with knowledge and intent.(Some axes of oppression we touched on: ableism, misogyny, racism, transphobia, misogynoir, xenophobia/imperialism, classism.)
(Some CS issues we discussed: AI/FR technology, medical/legal algorithms, surveillance tech.)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Examining systems of oppression, connecting socio-political systems to technology, thinking critically about the social impacts and repercussions of technology

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Unless serious changes are made to the curriculum to encourage more thoughtful debate and conversation, I would advise avoiding this class. These topics are very important to discuss, especially amongst a group of people (CS students) who don't typically interact with this kind of material or haven't in many years. That being said, from the onset it is very clear that if you disagree with the professor and the majority of the class, you're opinion is not welcomed. Rather than working to encourage people who haven't learned about this material to consider a different stance on it, you are outcasted and encouraged to drop the class, leading to there just being a bunch of poeple who have the same opinion as the professor. No critical thinking, and no debate.

response_text: I enjoyed the structure of the course— it was divided into two halves. In the first half, we were introduced to a lot of context on the types of inequalities in society. This broader understanding built a foundation for the second half, which focused in on how these topics translated to a computing context. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was introduced to so many female artists but what I really enjoyed was learning about their faults. They are complex beings and as exceptional as they were they also were flawed in the same way that we celebrate male artists who are extremely problematic (Picasso…) so this was a great introduction to what women are capable of in the art world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned a lot about women in visual arts and their different roles as artists, patrons, collectors, etc.; different challenges they faced; how they have been represented historically; how traditionally gendered analyses have influenced popular narratives; and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned a lot about women artists, the contexts in which they operated, how to conduct visual analysis, and how to question existing art historical practices of telling women’s stories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Visually analyzing art created by female artists, creating an art exhibit and understand museum layout, and speaking about how spotlight female artists

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I better understand now how to view art and appreciate it. I also know how to consider the history of the art when I look at it. I also better understand women's place in art history and how they were overlooked and what discrimination they faced.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about individual women artists, obstacles that they have faced throughout art history and ways in which they have met these challenges, and issues in art historical and museum practice regarding representation and treatment of women artists. The course explored many different ways in which women were involved in the visual arts in the early modern period: women as makers of art, women as patrons and collectors of art, and representations of women in the visual arts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the readings each week– they were well-organized thematically and provided a variety of angles and perspectives on each week's topic. It was interesting to compare/contrast them in our reading responses and discussion questions. The classes in the Nasher, Rubinstein Library, and Duke Gardens were a wonderful addition (especially the Rubinstein Library– I loved being able to engage with primary sources that were right in front of us!). Professor Hogan was always kind, understanding, and approachable and wanted her students to be comfortable and included in class, which resulted in a great learning environment. I also just want to say that this was a wonderful idea for a course and I hope that it is routinely offered in the future so that many more students can learn about this interesting and valuable topic!
