question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Technical filmmaking abilities in Premiere pro, the ability to analyze the human relationship with nature through a queer lens, and the ability to analyze difficult texts on the subject of the human relationship with nature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much from this class. It was truly transformative—I developed new ways of thinking about climate change through the lens of gender and sexuality, which I'd never thought of before. It opened up my mind! I learned how to make a documentary, which was a feat.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Improved my Premiere Pro skills to create a documentary
2. Reading complex texts to understand how climate and culture are interrelated
3. Interviewing and communicating with community partners and how to tell their stories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned SO MUCH in this course!! Not only was I able to learn about the theory of feminism, environmental activism, etc, I was also able to apply my knowledge in a meaningful way with a product to show for it. Lauren was very helpful when teaching Premiere Pro. Her office hours were especially helpful for getting to work with her 1:1. I feel confident in my ability to create a film on my own after taking this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
how to critically analyze texts
how to create a film!
how to use premiere pro
how to do a group film
list goes on! the profs created an unforgettable experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class pushed me to think about gender and ecology in ways I had never considered- how plants communicate, the importance of reciprocity, and practices of collective care. I also learned how to make a film from start to finish: interviewing people, editing footage, adding music—skills I had never explored before. As a computer science major, this was the kind of class I never knew I needed. At Duke, it’s easy to stay in the bubble of econ, finance, and compsci, but courses like this are what the Trinity Arts & Sciences education is really about—broadening your perspective and becoming more well-rounded. As I head into senior year and speak with past seniors, I’m thinking more about what I want to take with me from Duke. For me, that means building deeper relationships and being more present in the community I’ve lived in for four years. This class helped me start doing that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Filmmaking
- Critical thinking about text, filmmaking, artistry, lived experiences
- Connecting ideas through multiple medium

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: What did we not learn? We engaged with texts from feminist theory to science fiction about aliens, we presented and discussed weekly, we worked together on the Duke Campus Farm, we made sauerkraut together, we worked closely and intensively in small groups and with community partners and activists to make 10 minute documentary films. We learned how to use Premiere Pro, how to connect with community members unaffiliated with Duke who we would otherwise never have met, and how to mesh all of the experiences from this class into one hugely fulfilling project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) I learned video editing skills in Premiere Pro. 2) I learned how to interview people and how to guide them to answer questions that are part of a broader theme. 3) I improved my teamwork skills and to play a supportive role when working with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course, I developed (and fine-tuned) filmmaking, editing, and software skills by curating student-led film projects in collaboration with community partners in the Triangle area. I gained insights from course texts that engaged with queer and feminist theory, developing new ways of thinking about the current climate crisis, of being in relation with one another, and how (both tangibly and theoretically) to live and embody these concepts (not just read, think, and write about them). I learned how to work collaboratively on a long-term creative project in such a way that builds on our individual and collective strengths. I explored new elements of our relationship to our environment, from our biological traits to the science behind our gut-brain connection.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Of all of the classes I took this semester, this class provided me one of the most enriching and insightful experiences. From our weekly assigned readings and discussion posts, I learned how to critically read and analyze complex texts related to ecology and feminist studies. From our visits to the Duke Campus Farm, I learned about the farm's history and also engaged with specific practices including mulching, weeding, and broad-forking. Throughout the process of completing our final project, I learned how to make a short documentary and all of the moving parts that such an initiative requires (eg. recording interviews, writing narration, drafting a storyboard, editing).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: These instructors were two of the best I have had at Duke and were really detrimental to my learning and progression in the course. They facilitated my learning by always being available to speak both formally and informally. For example, I spent three hours in Lauren's office with my final film and she willingly helped me make it a product I was proud of.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were amazing at facilitating in class discussion and creating an environment where I felt safe to share my ideas even when I was not fully confident in my abilities in the area. In the future, I would most definitely keep the seminar style of this class as I felt that was most important to my learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the texts built on each other in a really constructive way, which was great for my learning. I enjoyed the discussion posts because I could learn from my fellow students. I also really enjoyed hearing about Lauren's work as someone who is working in the documentary film world. She's doing some really amazing work. The Premiere Pro workshops were also wonderful, as well as the short practice videos (they were also just really fun). Also, definitely keep the farm work day! That was so great.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There were lots of discussions, presentations and technical workshops that allowed us all to engage with the material and each others' ideas well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the timing of the class, meeting one time per week. The discussion questions helped me organize my thoughts before coming to class. I also really enjoyed being able to create videos on my own before contributing to a larger group project. I think a lot of this class relied on individuals doing the initial work and then collaborating in order to further comprehension.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: they opened up office hours nearly every hour of the day. they allowed us to be ourselves to the fullest, something not always respected at Duke. they created a safe space to speak about issues that feel burdensome to speak about at Duke. eternally grateful for how they create in-class time to work on our projects and make sure to facilitate our own working time outside of class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were absolutely essential to my learning experience. They went above and beyond—always available for guidance, support, and feedback. I spent countless hours in Lauren’s office with my roommate and teammate as she helped us shape our film, offering both technical help and insight. Their dedication created a learning environment where we felt supported every step of the way.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were just incredible. As a junior at Duke, this is easily the most profound course I have taken. The instructors were attentive, caring, and knowledgeable. Saskia helped guide and provoke discussions with thoughtful questions and a diverse array of activities to simulate our thinking. Lauren had so much insight to share and I could not imagine someone more supportive to learn filmmaking for the first time from. They were both receptive and open to helping students however possible and whenever necessary. I always felt excited going to class because we were doing something new and talking about something meaningful, which expanded my broader knowledge of climate, justice, and their intersection. We participated in a lot of hands-on activities, like visiting the Duke Campus Farm and making sauerkraut, that helped me grasp texts in a fun and meaningful way. I was also pushed outside of my comfort

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The co-teaching style of this class was perfect for the structure and material. Professor Cornes engages more directly with the readings, while Professor Henschel handles the film end of things. The activities like the trip to the farm and sauerkraut workshop were not only bonding and fun but also relevant to the material and intellectually engaging. The film was the biggest part of the class, and it was one of the most challenging but also most fulfilling projects I've ever done.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was structured very well. It was a great balance of experiential learning at the Duke Campus Farm, creative exploration while filmmaking, and intellectual stimulation through course readings. I would definitely keep the visits to the Duke Campus Farm and filmmaking lessons for future classes. Through these unique experiences, and considering that people from different majors enroll in the class, they all have the opportunity to try something new and maybe find a new passion, like I did for filmmaking.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Each day of class, Saskia and Lauren began with a prompt, encouraging us to reflect on something new or exciting or even pick up on a thread or concept from the previous week. What seemed like such a small moment at the beginning of each class ended up bringing us closer together, celebrating our individual wins as a class and offering glimpses of joy when weeks were particularly difficult. Saskia and Lauren united us, creating an environment centered around care, community, and curiosity, creating space for intellectual growth and even humility, recognizing that we do not always have the answers. Lauren and Saskia were always available to field questions about our film, about the content of the course that we found particularly challenging, fascinating, or frustrating. Lauren offered a space to develop new film editing skills using Premiere Pro, providing countless opportunities to meet during office hours to learn new workarounds and shortcuts to enhance the power of our project.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated being able to read and discuss a variety of readings throughout the semester, and I think that the weekly required discussion posts encouraged me to engage with each text more thoughtfully. My favorite component of the class was, likewise, the process of creating our short documentary. It was an incredibly memorable and transformative learning experience to be able to connect with community members and try to communicate a story in a new way.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The way Saskia and Lauren weaved through texts, films, class discussions, and the filmmaking component was masterful. This is an unforgettable class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We got to read and watch diverse kinds of materials with topics I have never thought about.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was a truly stimulating experience—we explored a wide range of topics, read thought-provoking texts, watched powerful films, conducted interviews, and even created our own. The variety of learning methods made the course both dynamic and impactful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Digesting different forms of media, getting out into the community, collaborating with and highlighting narratives from community partners, engaging in a full filmmaking process, critically analyzing text, drawing connections between different authors, styles, and ideas, hands-on activities directed by students and the professors, presenting our own takeaways from a fim/reading. Everything about this course was stimulating for me personally and led to a very high level of engagement that was refreshing to have from a Duke course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because we were doing something different every week. One week, we would go to the Duke Campus Farm and participate in the Community Work Days. Another week, we would have a filmmaking workshop in the Center for Documentary Studies and learn new technical skills for editing. I also felt like our class because a family by the end of the semester. I looked forward to coming to class to feel like a part of my class community.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found this course's multimedia approach to be highly intellectually stimulating. It allowed us to cut through and across academic houses, from intellectual “authorities” on the Anthropocene to visionary Indigenous thinkers such as Robin Kimmerer and Tommy Pico's powerful poetics.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Lauren and Saskia's teaching made this class thoroughly stimulating. Whether it was reading our discussion posts each week, asking thought-provoking questions to encourage class conversation, or presenting class concepts through engaging presentations, Saskia helped cultivate an environment where students were excited and interested in what we were learning. Lauren, likewise, brought her invaluable technical expertise when supporting our learning as beginner filmmakers. I greatly valued her feedback on our one-minute videos and full-length documentary, and our final project benefitted immensely from her insight. My favorite aspect of this class was the ability to visit and directly engage with the Duke Campus Farm community. I also appreciate our having had the special opportunity to speak with filmmakers who visited our class and provided additional feedback on our documentaries.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! New way of learning for me through documentary and video work and team based projects.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a course that will challenge you to think in new ways and consider ideas through a new lens. There is an important intersectionality between these ideas that are often not considered.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class - I came in knowing nothing about the topics and walked away having learned so much. It was incredibly rewarding to learn how to make a film and to understand how to communicate ideas in a way that’s powerful and resonant. Plus, you’ll automatically be engaged with the local community, which is a great opportunity for students who struggle to find time to connect beyond campus.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come in with an open mind. Be willing to learn from others and share your own ideas. Think deeply and embrace all parts of the filmmaking process. Enjoy it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it, but be prepared to give it your all! Be prepared for technical difficulties, but you will overcome them!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that you'll be a different person by the end of the semester. By taking this class, you will learn how to be compassionate toward others and how to be an active member of the community. You will realize that making a difference even in just your immediate community is meaningful and impacts the lives of others. I would also say that taking this class will make you see the world in a different way. For me, it made me realize that films are not just for entertainment; they can play an activist role and be a form of resistance.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was truly the most powerful, rewarding, collaborative, and intellectually challenging course I have taken in my four years at Duke. I recommend this course to those interested in gender studies, environmental justice, queer theory, farming, especially if these are new or unfamiliar concepts to you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I could not recommend this class enough to any student who is interested in the climate, ecology, gender theory, community-engaged learning, or documentary filmmaking. Whether a student has a background in these subjects or an interest they want to explore, this class offers such a special opportunity to engage with any or all of these areas. Taking this class taught me how to consider gender theory and climate change - two topics that I had not previously assumed to be connected - in relation to each other. It was unforgettable to be able to learn by physically being at the Duke Campus Farm and building relationships with the people working there. This class showed me what it can look like to try something new, become more aware of my own positionality as a student, and engage with my environment (including the land and its people) more conscientiously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about the intersection of climate change and gender theory. 
I explored a new way of being tested through videos/creating documentaries and teamwork. 
I developed presentation skills through our class presentations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Technical filmmaking abilities in Premiere pro, the ability to analyze the human relationship with nature through a queer lens, and the ability to analyze difficult texts on the subject of the human relationship with nature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much from this class. It was truly transformative—I developed new ways of thinking about climate change through the lens of gender and sexuality, which I'd never thought of before. It opened up my mind! I learned how to make a documentary, which was a feat.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Improved my Premiere Pro skills to create a documentary
2. Reading complex texts to understand how climate and culture are interrelated
3. Interviewing and communicating with community partners and how to tell their stories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned SO MUCH in this course!! Not only was I able to learn about the theory of feminism, environmental activism, etc, I was also able to apply my knowledge in a meaningful way with a product to show for it. Lauren was very helpful when teaching Premiere Pro. Her office hours were especially helpful for getting to work with her 1:1. I feel confident in my ability to create a film on my own after taking this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
how to critically analyze texts
how to create a film!
how to use premiere pro
how to do a group film
list goes on! the profs created an unforgettable experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class pushed me to think about gender and ecology in ways I had never considered- how plants communicate, the importance of reciprocity, and practices of collective care. I also learned how to make a film from start to finish: interviewing people, editing footage, adding music—skills I had never explored before. As a computer science major, this was the kind of class I never knew I needed. At Duke, it’s easy to stay in the bubble of econ, finance, and compsci, but courses like this are what the Trinity Arts & Sciences education is really about—broadening your perspective and becoming more well-rounded. As I head into senior year and speak with past seniors, I’m thinking more about what I want to take with me from Duke. For me, that means building deeper relationships and being more present in the community I’ve lived in for four years. This class helped me start doing that.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Filmmaking
- Critical thinking about text, filmmaking, artistry, lived experiences
- Connecting ideas through multiple medium

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: What did we not learn? We engaged with texts from feminist theory to science fiction about aliens, we presented and discussed weekly, we worked together on the Duke Campus Farm, we made sauerkraut together, we worked closely and intensively in small groups and with community partners and activists to make 10 minute documentary films. We learned how to use Premiere Pro, how to connect with community members unaffiliated with Duke who we would otherwise never have met, and how to mesh all of the experiences from this class into one hugely fulfilling project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) I learned video editing skills in Premiere Pro. 2) I learned how to interview people and how to guide them to answer questions that are part of a broader theme. 3) I improved my teamwork skills and to play a supportive role when working with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course, I developed (and fine-tuned) filmmaking, editing, and software skills by curating student-led film projects in collaboration with community partners in the Triangle area. I gained insights from course texts that engaged with queer and feminist theory, developing new ways of thinking about the current climate crisis, of being in relation with one another, and how (both tangibly and theoretically) to live and embody these concepts (not just read, think, and write about them). I learned how to work collaboratively on a long-term creative project in such a way that builds on our individual and collective strengths. I explored new elements of our relationship to our environment, from our biological traits to the science behind our gut-brain connection.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Of all of the classes I took this semester, this class provided me one of the most enriching and insightful experiences. From our weekly assigned readings and discussion posts, I learned how to critically read and analyze complex texts related to ecology and feminist studies. From our visits to the Duke Campus Farm, I learned about the farm's history and also engaged with specific practices including mulching, weeding, and broad-forking. Throughout the process of completing our final project, I learned how to make a short documentary and all of the moving parts that such an initiative requires (eg. recording interviews, writing narration, drafting a storyboard, editing).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I could not recommend this class enough to any student who is interested in the climate, ecology, gender theory, community-engaged learning, or documentary filmmaking. Whether a student has a background in these subjects or an interest they want to explore, this class offers such a special opportunity to engage with any or all of these areas. Taking this class taught me how to consider gender theory and climate change - two topics that I had not previously assumed to be connected - in relation to each other. It was unforgettable to be able to learn by physically being at the Duke Campus Farm and building relationships with the people working there. This class showed me what it can look like to try something new, become more aware of my own positionality as a student, and engage with my environment (including the land and its people) more conscientiously.

I also improved my reading skills, pulling out the important parts of a piece and pulling out evidence to support it, and also my speaking skills as we did a lot of discussions in class.

This class led to such thoughtful and interesting discussions, and was one of my favorites I took this semester. It was a fun way to intersect my interests in visual arts with a subject I had not formally delved into at Duke, GSF. The class does not require a lot of work but is rewarding to be a part of nonetheless, and the readings and pieces we examine are so interesting!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it seriously even if breast cancer might not sound a near future or something familiar, tangible. Its relationship to gender, sexism, feminism is integral and critical to learn as a global citizen.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is really intellectually stimulating. You don't need to have any prior knowlege of the topic to really get something out of this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There are 3 "formal" writings which are only 3-4 full pages and 3-4 "informal writings" which are 2-3 paragraphs each (and a final reflection paper). You are allowed to "re-use" content from your informal writings to help guide your formal writings, in fact they are set up to prepare you for the formal writing. So really not too bad at all in terms of workload. Readings, on average, take no more than 3 hours per week.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say be prepared for a lot of readings and many formal and informal writing assignments. you will get a lot of the class but you also will have to put in a lot of work! I would definitely recommend it for any pre-meds.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I strengthened my video editing skills and understanding of premier pro. I learned about algorithmic bias and the ways that can harm society. I learned about the history of silicon valley and how women have been excluded from it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of foundational information about the importance of feminism in both real life and the digital space, the prevalence of sexism in Silicon Valley, and various online spaces perpetuating sexist narratives. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the increasing role of AI in the technology industry, the bro culture in tech, and how to use Premiere Pro.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned and became extremely proficient in Adobe Premire.
I also was able to synthesize social theory with contemporary tech issues
I developed a way of thinking of seeing technology not as neutral, but shaped by and reinforcing power structures (race, gender, class, ability).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more broadly about media and how it relates and shapes the world of feminism. I learned a lot more about the tech industry and the gender discrimination that has taken place over the years, especially in Silicon Valley. I lastly learned how to use interfaces such as Premier Pro to become more comfortable with video making and editing, which will be very helpful in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The one minute videos on Premiere Pro, the final project, and the forum posts all encouraged my engagement with the course. I would keep the one minute videos and the final project. I also loved group work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of this class was dynamic, inclusive, and deeply engaging. Professors Gelfand and Henschel cultivated a space where theory and practice met in meaningful ways. The combination of seminar-style discussions, creative media assignments (One Minute videos, Zine workshop), and collaborative final projects allowed for a multifaceted learning experience that accommodated a wide range of learning styles.For future years, I would strongly recommend keeping the combination of theory-based readings, digital production, and the reflective essay as core pillars of the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: This class is extremely repetitive, so if any given student likes to engage with new information regularly this in no the class for them. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned, through producing the film, how to connect with an audience in a way that is meaningful and inspires action.
2. Through the readings, I learned how to think very critically about the media that we consume and the ideas and ideologies that we take for granted on a daily basis.
3. I learned about the utter importance of teaching people how to act as a collective, rather than build isolated boxes around people with different ideas and beliefs. So often today, people judge each other without even truly knowing each other, based on a general idea of who they think they are. We are judged by society's perceptions of ourselves, and sometimes it's hard to bridge this gap—but it's essential for us to find common ground with each other if we are to make meaningful change.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: To succeed in this course, you should be familiar with both science and humanities. You'll have to parse through scientific studies, as well as read through dense humanities theories. You will also have to write a lot about both of these topics. This course can be a bit disorganized, so don't hesitate to ask the professors to clarify anything that you are confused about. They are both genuinely interested in the topic, and they try to ensure that their students are engaged and learning. Participation and group work are also a large part of this class and they make up most of your grade.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically think and explore different academic texts varying from more digestible personal stories to dense academic texts. I have learned a lot about trans theory, critical theory, and also feminist studies as a whole. Also being able to engage in discussion is a skill I have learned more of. Learning how to write academic papers as well as answer to larger prompts that aren't looking for a specific answer but allow you to develop your own opinion and learn how to write arguments and provide evidence for that is a great skill I have learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Knowledge of trans studies and trans "ways of thinking," improved writing skills, improved ways of thinking connecting readings together.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Understanding of what the field of trans studies is
What affects are and how that is helpful for analysis
The importance of forcing ideas and concepts from today onto experiences from the past

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class gave me a new perspective on neoliberal hyper focus on identity and the purification of those categories, like cis and trans. It also gave me a new way of thinking about the role of the state in the creation and maintenance of things like sex and race, and also how medicolegal processes formed those as inseparable identifications. It was also really interesting to learn about non normative gendered subjects in Weimar/Nazi Germany and   (post) dictatorship Argentina and how fascist persecution is not homogeneous and relies in part on economic utility to the state.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned:
1) How "trans" goes beyond just individuals that identify as transgender (and how this conceptualization of transgender as relegated to personal identity is a more recent idea, and may not be how trans actually functions in the world today)
2) How biological sex is a more complicated and political topic than a previously thought, especially (but not limited to) how it and its relation to gender are racialized
3) How to synthesize and congeal my thoughts on a complicated, often confusing topic into an essay

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Zavier Nunn is an amazing professor and person to engage with that really gets his students thinking and facilitates us personally and in class with thinking of society, the questions he poses, and thinking interpersonally. The course has helped me also reflect on myself, my writing, and my own thinking a lot which I am so grateful for. The feedback Dr. Nunn provides is very constructvie and helpful that has allowed me to grasp academic writing much better.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussions in class on the readings were very engaging and helped process and understand more difficult parts of the readings. I enjoyed and learned a lot from all the readings and think differently now as a result.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked how the class was structured into five different focuses of trans studies and it felt like they really built on each other. I also think that the way each day was structured starting with our key takeaways and questions and then Zavier asking us questions to guide us through each text facilitated my learning and make it easier to grasp the more complicated texts and connect each one to previous ones. I think the topics of the two short papers and the freedom of the last one were good and I felt pushed to think more deeply about complicated and difficult to answer questions in trans studies.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the consistent structure of reading selections before class and discussing them seminar-style during the class was effective. I think the 3 questions he introduced about midway through (main takeaway, connections to other readings, and any confusions) helped facilitate discussions, as well as call back to previous readings, recognizing connections between topics and "eras" of trans studies.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The small group environment also facilitated a sort of understanding and knowledge exchange not seen in larger lectures. I got to know my classmates on a deeper level and talk over issues that concern us and think critically and in larger contexts together. The types of texts made the class stimulating as well as Dr. Nunn's passion for his topic and career along with his interest in engaging and learning from us as well thorugh these texts. The harder texts were hard but he brought us through them and explained them so eloquently.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned to look at situations from multiple perspectives 
2) I learned to question why our systems are structured the way they are

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned new ways of viewing the world and combatting bias.
1) The effect of racism and disease narratives on the world in the past and present.
2) The way disease has been used as a weapon.
3) How to discuss bias while avoiding bias.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the world around me and specifically understand drivers of conflict and violence through the lense of marginalized populations such as queer communities, women, those of different ethnicities and races, immigrants, and more. In addition, learning how to read dense texts, ethnographies, and articles was a big part of the course, and I learned how to digest, understand, and analyse these texts as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a deeper understanding of the history of racialized and gendered medicine. I also learned how to evaluate medical/scientific interventions from a racially-conscious perspective and learned how to read texts better. Many of the people in the class are interested in pursuing healthcare professions so I think this class is particularly relevant and useful for us to critically evaluate the healthcare system and the how medicine has advanced through the expense of marginalized groups.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I understood how historical context and biopolitics contribute to modern healthcare implementations for all groups who don't fit the standard cis, white, male body type. Along with this, I learned about who the actors vs. the subjects were in many cases, and how racism is inherent in many medical practices we pursue today. (For example, I honestly had NO idea that black women slaves were the unwilling subjects who gave us the practice of gynecology we have today.) I also learned how to digest large readings and get the main takeaways as we discussed them during class. As a cis white woman, I do want to mention how I came into this class not having a ton of background on these subjects and I now have learned so much that I will apply in the medical field - like taking into account the history of practices, understanding how livelihoods and backgrounds should be considered, and understanding how my own biases could impact my work on any individual.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to engage in seminar/discussion based learning. The class is also reading heavy (~150 pages a week), but it only met once so it was doable. I learned a lot about colonial legacies in healthcare

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained insight into the feasibility and ethical responsibilities in conducting ethnographic research/ the obligations you have when discussing a group's history, specifics about the creation of medical specialties and the system of public health in the US overall, and a troubling of the solutions I had previously devised for how to fix the US healthcare system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The work that was done with Derrida and deconstruction helped me to develop greater critical thinking skills as it broadened my mindset and consider how the definitions and norms that we think of today can be reconstructed or questioned based on their rationale and validity. Our time on Kant and Mahmood has helped me to consider the role that ethics might truly play. Most poignantly, the idea that American ethics in doing no harm is not truly virtue. Instead, considering how I might reconsider my own decisions and everyday life in the pursuit of cultivating virtue. Finally, Althusser and Foucault have allowed me to question the origins of the various norms that I take for granted.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take this class if it counts for your major and especially if it doesn't. The readings can be hard to grasp sometimes although theres no expectation on how much you grasp at initial reading and afterwards even just though you have a midterm and final paper where you are given many prompts to chose from and over two weeks to complete. The demand of the class also is minimal and doesn't feel like a lot since its not like you are being tested the next class on what you read; the class promotes you understanding and reading at your own pace the texts to be able to understand what is being said in class. Take this course esepcially if you want to read more and read these types of texts and engage with them in a relaxed and growth-centered manner but dont have the time in your personal life or other classes to do so.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about the history of the term decolonization through the lens of decolonial movements and speakers. Sources we read/viewed ranged from extremely old to very recent postcolonial history. We learned about Decolonial movements globally, ideologies that made up these movements, and different ways to view the idea of decolonization as both a noun and a verb.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) What exactly is decolonization?
2) What do criticisms of decolonization look like? Why are they problematic?
3) Where is the intersection between violence and decolonization

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three specific things I have learned is what does decolonization mean (or what can it mean), how colonialism and the process of decolonization can be a shared or universal experience, and has improved my research abilities for finding primary/secondary sources for a research paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: decolonial methods, awareness of the ways colonization affects the world, imperialism, decolonial movements, primary source analysis, settler colonialism, how violence exists in other forms aside from physical

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think more critically and historically about current movements. A better idea of what decolonization means to today on turtle island. What role art plays in the culture of revolution.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about how decolonization is defined in different parts of the world and how our colonized approach to learning, living, and being skews the way we interpret and understand decolonization on a deeper level.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three specific things I learned in this course were how to approach history from a decolonial perspective, how to view colonizing experiences in an anti-imperial and anti-capitalist context, and also how to consider the relationships between different social justice movements and decolonization.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Before this class, I did not have an in-depth understanding of decolonization. However, after taking this course, I have a better grasp of how decolonization as a movement and thought has evolved from thinkers like Fanon, Said, and Cesaire to more contemporary scholars like Mohanty, Tapalde, and Tuck and Yang; the importance of centering indigenous voices in decolonization; and primary source analysis. All in all, I have more questions than answers, but I think that's exactly the point of this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Writing a research paper starting from primary sources
2. Specific histories of decolonization in Africa and Asia
3. International organizing in the 20th century

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Kathi was a phenomenal instructor. She maintained the perfect balance of lecture and discussion. I appreciated how well she moderated our discussions and encouraged everyone to participate. Another thing that I really appreciated about the classroom environment was that everyone was respectful and open-minded. People felt comfortable disagreeing with each other and it really allowed our class to explore all sides of an issue or debate. Also, Kathi was very welcoming and encouraging of all kinds of contributions. I never felt afraid to speak up because she let us know that every comment was important and valuable to our discussion, no matter how small. She also kept the conversation moving forward and guided it very well to ensure we covered a lot in each class and didn't get stuck in a repetitive loop of everyone repeating the same idea.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: this course was instrumental in bringing light to the ways in which societal normas and gender/ racial hierarchies manifest in many different ways. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my ability to look at the deeper meanings of elements of popular culture and how they can subtly and overtly portray both positive and negative notions of gender hierarchies. I also learned more about how to analyze the elements of filmmaking such as lighting, sound, editing, etc. in relation to how they contribute to the messaging of the films. Finally, I developed a keener awareness of the ways in which popular culture has affected me and has subconsciously affected my thoughts and perceptions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that questioning, wondering, and challenging stated beliefs are meaningful and valuable ways to think about complex/nuanced topics. I also learned how to combine and differentiate my thoughts from personal experience and identity from those that originate from more formal academic papers. This class also changed my perception of how I can contribute to group seminars in smaller groups vs larger classes, as well as synchronously vs asynchronously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I learned about different ways to think about intimacy theoretically
- I learned one of the three skills offered from our final project
- I learned how to better communicate during class discussions when I may not be super comfortable with the topic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The biggest "knowledge" takeaway from this class was the ability to think about something abstract but ever-present in our lives that seems elusive and undefinable and to give it life. I think unlike some other classes that seek "productive" skills like coding this class allowed me to learn a more life-relevant skill of articulating complex ideas with interconnected and intricate histories. The first thing I learned was about history, it was the backbone of understanding the course's definitions of intimacy. The second thing I learned was about the ways that novels and films reveal layers of intimacy that feel relevant to life. The final thing I learned was about ways to interact more deeply with my classmates.

response_text: Through this course, I learned about debates about porn, the intersection of sexuality with other identity categories, and the history of sexuality through conversations about immigration, military, etc. There were so many readings that made me think in new ways, and was able to carry many of the conversations we had outside of class to my friends and family.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned about how one could argue that both sexuality and desire are socially constructed.
2) I learned about how quare theory resolves the problem that queer theory has with addressing intersectionality and with portraying queer experience as a monolith.
3) I learned about how the analog and digital boundaries of queer space can be defined and can overlap.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I genuinely think that this class pushed me on many fronts. It taught me how to do a class which such dense complex readings, it challenged me to think critically on my feet in class, and it kept me challenged but in a way that never felt un-welcomed / unhealthy.I really appreciated learning about different thinkers (which I apply both inside and outside of class now)-- and bringing this through the rest of the course. Seriously an amazing course... I was very nervous to take to at first but I haven't regretted it for a moment. This taught me also to follow my interests -- despite fears -- because it will be much more rewarding to learn about a topic you actually enjoy and to challenge yourself opposed to simply taking an easy-A class just for the transcript boost.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: (1) I learned various terms and concepts in Ethics, Philosophy, and Cultural Anthropology. (2) I developed theoretical frameworks which have changed the way I look at the world. (3) I learned about hope. First theoretically, then in terms of medicine, home, and crisis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Deep reading and analyzing of text. Being able to connect the various theories learned at the start of the class with new material learned. Thinking in a more ethical and philosophical mindset.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to compare and connect different texts from throughout the semester. I also developed my close reading skills. Finally, I learned how to take texts from authors and add my own interpretation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Anne Allison is fantastic. She is astoundingly brilliant on all fronts, has thought a lot about the topic of hope, and genuinely cares about what your thoughts are on the readings. Her reading-recaps are beyond helpful (she takes dense readings and makes them actually digestible), she is always able to answer questions, and she too applies the thinkers that we learned about early on in the semester on a daily basis. Professor Allison is a major component for why this class was so amazing and I think that she really went above and beyond to facilitate learning, engagement, and understanding in her class. Further, I think that she organized the class in a very intentional way. It was very smart to have thinkers first, then medicine, home, and finally disaster. She clearly thought about the structure of the course and every reading that we did / how it would weave together into conversations in class -- and I really commend her for how it played out throughout the semester. Professor Allison was also extremely available for help outside of class (I personally met with her a bunch) and she was overwhelmingly helpful each time. Finally, I really have appreciated the thought that goes into paper prompts because they prompt critical thinking that is engaging, intellectual, but also fun and enjoyable. Her and Anton did a great job with this -- serious kudos to them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Allison would guide the class through each reading. She would outline the general argument of a reading, draw connections to other readings, and emphasize the key takeaways. Some of the readings were more philosophical and dense, so I appreciated this method of instruction. Professor Allison was also incredibly encouraging. She was excited for us to participate, would help us articulate our points, and would refer back to our comments in later classes. I always felt heard and supported in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having the circle discussions and hearing all the unique insight Anton (TA), Professor Allison, and fellow students had to all the papers we read. The final discussion in replacement of the final essay was nice.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really loved the circle discussions, because it did not feel like a lecture at all. I also loved how we all would read the readings before class and come with our own individual interpretations before hearing what the professors thought or what my classmates thought.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I genuinely think that each piece was picked for a reason and I really enjoyed doing readings that pushed me out of my comfort zone and engaging in class.Talks were always engaging and Professor Allison always posed thought-provoking questions to the class which was always challenging, yet enjoyable.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I have never been a student who was good at close reading and analyzing texts for more complex meanings so it was a very different classroom experience for me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thought it was incredibly intellectually stimulating because of Dr. Allison’s breadth of experience. She also is a great orator and makes everything interesting. Regardless, the class material was already interesting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
- DO THE READINGS. I cannot stress this enough. 
- Try to really understand all the thinkers that you learn about in the first unit because they will all come up in conversation throughout the rest of the course and doing this would create a foundation to make the rest of the class easier.
- Just have fun with it! it is challenging but incredibly rewarding. You don't need to understand everything fully, just try your best
- Start your essays as early as possible - the prompts are long and really thought-provoking, which means leaving it to the last minute is not really possible
- Also meet with professor Allison outside of class! She really is the best!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Allison is an amazing teacher, and I strongly recommend this course. Weekly readings are interesting, and the two short papers were creative and engaging.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it if even mildly interested in any of the units covered in class or wanting to have a break from all STEM classes. Opens up new ways of thinking and discussing a very relevant/ever present concept of hope.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! Make sure to stay on top of readings- if you do it’s very interesting and manageable, but if you fall behind on readings, you get less out of class discussions and the work can pile up quickly.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: i learned how to read philosophy (i had never before); how to write about philosophy and understand philosophical topics. specifically i learned about simone weil's attention and affliction; simone de beauvoir's focus on freedom, justice, responsibility and feminism; and iris murdoch and other writers' ideas on morality

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

- The attention journals helped me ground my learning in everyday life and always apply things i learn with the help of attention

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about looking at literature through philosophy.
I came in with no prior knowledge of Weil, Beauvoir, and Murdoch, but I feel I have a very strong grasp on them and their philosophies now.
I also developed skills in creating a concise presentation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Just as Simone Weil wrote in her essays, in the right use of schoolwork, attention is extensively practiced. So I guess the most important three things I learned are attention to others and other things, Weil, Beauvoir, and Murdoch’s visions of existence, and of course essay writing methods.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Became intimately familiar with philosophies of Simone Weil, Simone de Beauvoir, and Iris Murdoch through close readings. Learned ethics in a way that was immediately applicable to everyday life. Gained insights about the influence of these thinkers on one another, particularly Simone Weil of whom I had close to no knowledge of before entering the course. One of my favorite things was when Professor Moi filled in historical/philosophical context around these thinkers (wartime, surrounding literature, Wittgenstein, Hegel, etc)--made it feel less like narrowing in on these random philosophers in a vacuum.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned about the philosophies and moral frameworks of Weil, Murdoch, and Beauvoir
2) I recognized ways in which these philosophical theories resonated with me and have a fresh perspective on my own behavior and way of living. 
3) I have become more conscious of the ways in which I do and don't pay attention in my life, and have begun cultivating that skill in my own behavior.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- i loved the seminar structured way of teaching that was interspersed with explanations of other philosophers (ie i liked professor moi's connections of weil, beauvoir, and murdoch with wittgenstein, cavell, and plato) because they not only allowed me to think deeper about the concepts i learn, but also open up new territories for me to explore in the future
- the weekly attention journals are also very helpful, because it forces me to sit down and reflect on the philosophy and also put things i learn into practice (paying attention)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Moi encouraged genuine reflection with our attention journals. These were not graded on the A-F scale, which allowed them to be purely for our own building of the skill of attention without having to pander or have a grade in the back of our minds. I would definitely keep this part of the course. I also found Professor Moi's lectures interesting. The breaking up of the three philosophers into three separate parts rather than going between them also made them digestible so that they didn't get convoluted.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Absolutely, when the material gets a bit too hard, Professor Moi made slides to accommodate and overall the in-class discussions were very fruitful. And I really liked the idea of using Slack channel to talk about difficult concepts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Smaller readings allowed me to pay closer attention to each text and get more out of subsequent lectures and discussions. I liked the attention journals as a way to keep me closely engaged with the texts throughout the week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought that in terms of content, the course flowed quite nicely. I thought beginning with Weil and ending with Murdoch (from our big three names) was the ideal order, with Weil's concept of attention framing the whole course and Murdoch's vision-based moral theory bringing together attention and action, as well as offering a more realistic and individualized moral approach (compared to Weil's saintly expectations and Beauvoir's more politically-grounded perspective).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class if you are interesting in philosophy, literature, theory or anything related at all. Note that this is not a feminist philosophy class, more so a class about women philosophers. I think these are philosophers that are underrated in the academic canon, although Beauvoir is quite popular now. But definitely Simone Weil is an underrated writer and philosopher that everyone should read. Professor Moi is also a great teacher who understands students and the texts quite well. The amount of texts you read in this class is perfect. Long enough that you get a deep enough understanding of the philosopher, but also not too long so that it becomes unmanageable. The texts are also enlightening and perfectly difficult to understand so when you do get some insight it feels nice and illuminating.
