question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Different perspectives on and approaches to ethnography, as well as the challenges of doing it (in the "field" and in writing).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was very helpful in learning more about a Black anthropological canon and methods. Three things I learned were: different kinds of applicable methods in the discipline, like mapping, embodied ethnography, and fiction writing; career paths for anthropology PhDs outside of academia and how these scholars write accessibly for different audiences; and finally, I was able to do a creative, non-traditional final project that helped me formulate my dissertation research interests.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Think of different ways that ethnography is both output and method and of different ethnographic methodologies.
How popular culture can be read ethnographically.
Connections with other academics are important to know and develop.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course invite me to expand my understanding of what it means to do ethnography, especially as it relates to Black ethnographers. I gained a good definition of what ethnography is as well as the varying modes and methods with which people use to engage ethnography, including visual, digital, and performance aspects. As such, I'm thinking more about the modes and methods I engage with as it relates to my doctoral project. I also developed skills as it relates to engaging with and creating connections across materials.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learnt why intellectual biographies are important aspects of understanding key anthropological networks. This is a learning strategy I implemented in all my other classes and will continue doing so in the future. 
2. I learnt the MANY different ways of ethnographic methodology - visual, ethnographic film, performance, poetry, essay, digital. All of which is very useful as a grad student currently engaged in ethnographic field methods.
3. I absolutely loved the syllabus of the class. The class flowed so well and the final paper for the class let us make the paper useful for us as scholars. I will keep in mind this syllabus when it is my time to create a syllabus too.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciate the different media we engaged with in the class! They were engaging and effective at communicating the breadth of ethnography.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Tracie is a caring and attentive teacher who creates a positive and warm space of learning and dialogue. I like that Tracie always includes a poem/song to start the class, and lets the class lead converastion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor always provided a list of questions from the readings for us to discuss. As well as putting up key quotes from the readings. A very interesting component of the class was to consider the intellectual biographies of the authors we were reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: It was great to be able to engage with the many writer and scholars we engage with throughout the course. It was helpful to see the different ways that scholars could address similar themes. I also like the use of articles and book chapters rather than reading entire books. I found it easier to get engaged with and follow the readings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The intellectual bios, using a multi-modal style of teaching ethnographic methods and the ways in which Professor Canada made the class safe to discuss our own positionalities with regard to our own anthropological careers was immensely valuable to me and certainly something I want to borrow for my own teaching career.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was fantastic! It's not lost on me how much Prof. Canada labored to care for us as a seminar, and invited us to do the same for one another. From the construction of the syllabus to getting feedback midway through the semester to the feedback you left on our submissions, thank you! These acts of care made it possible for us to rigorously engage with the material of the class, and our learning was all the better for it. I also appreciate that you'd tell us how you decided on the syllabus and how you were thinking about the course as a whole; super helpful for future educators!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating with a wide range of anthropologists working in different areas/on topics that often had similar theoretical concerns, but distinct methods or approaches. Unlike most grad classes, which are usually about the instructor's highly specialized knowledge, this class was helpful for introducing students to a broad range of thinkers and anthropologists...and for many anthropologists who might never learn about Black studies or Black feminist theory I think this is a great class to offer.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: A variety of approaches, objects of study and connections to content that was outside academia.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Canada really created a classroom environment where everyone felt willing to share as we wrestled with both the course materials as well as our own projects and positionality within the academy. Professor Canada was willing to welcome our questions and help us think through things we may be struggling with.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The fact that the readings for the class were so well-thought out and flowed so well from one week to another made the class very stimulating for me. Questions that would come up in one week would always be answered in the week later or in the following weeks which made the class feel very complete.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: 10/10, no notes! You'll learn so much from this course, even if your research isn't necessarily about race or planning to use ethnography. It's a deep dive into themes of doing research and being a career academic across many genres and flavors! Take the class!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great for grad students who want to learn about what the actual methods of ethnography are BEFORE you take the methods class! This has been helpful as I figure out how to describe my project and think about writing grants.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It may not look like it at first glance but this class is a lot of work between all the writing that is required the reading responses and the final. While the end of semester project is open ended, you will be required to draw a red thread to your own work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Black Ethnographers provides a great opportunity to engage with the work of Black scholars, writers, and cultural producers. While most of the scholars engage with were anthropologists, the class appeals to all students interested in thinking through what it means to write about Black life and how to engage in decolonial methodologies and theorizing. Additionally, Tracie Canada is a great professor. She creates a classroom environment that is fun and exciting. I looked forward to the class each week.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The syllabus of the class is exceptional - especially from a decolonial position. This class is theoretical and methodological at the same time and Professor Canada is willing to meet you wherever in your career you are at to facilitate your learning!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. Critical reading & inquiry - 2. Sedgwick’s corpus - 3. Writing academically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: learned a lot about sedgwick's life and writing

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close reading, understanding the arc of a single scholar's work and thinking, critically evaluating and entering into academic discourse

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A close knowledge of one of the formative thinkers in queer theory, which generated further insights into various developments in the field; for instance, the move from "anti-homophobic" to "queer," the relationship between feminist theory and queer theory, and the affective turn. Close attention to the deployment of the personal and the meaning and troubles of identification and cross-identification.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Archival Research. The most important reason that I enroll in this course.
2. Learning to Sit with Ambiguity. This course taught me that not every question has a clear answer—and that’s okay. Through Sedgwick’s writing and our discussions, I became more comfortable with complexity, contradiction, and not knowing.
3. Collaborative Thinking. The seminar environment encouraged a slower, more relational way of thinking.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read in both paranoid and reparative modes. I became very familiar with the concept of the personal archive. This class expanded my idea of what analysis can look like, and I appreciated the extent of the freedom we were given in our identifications with Sedgwick and the playfulness involved in the critiques in that (non)relationship.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have a much better sense of the trajectory of Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick's career, the formation of Queer Theory as a field, and the main contributions Sedgwick made (triangulation, minoritizing/universalizing, the closet, the affective turn, illness, Proust). I also learned a lot about archival work and processes of memorialization.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Discussion based courses are helpful

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Wiegman adeptly balanced facilitating student-led discussion and working out of ideas and guiding the conversation in her voice and skill set. Even though we rarely finished the "writing on the board" exercises, it was helpful to have another medium to map out ideas. The visit to the archive as a group was also a very enriching and interesting experience and I enjoyed the more informal opportunity to work through ideas and objects.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The traditional seminar, conversational style worked well, including the attention to emotion/reaction. The mapping exercise for Epistemology of the Closet was helpful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The Archive Diary and Exhibit Review were especially effective in deepening my engagement with the course. The Archive Diary encouraged hands-on, reflective research that made Sedgwick’s work feel personal and alive, while the Exhibit Review allowed me to think critically about curation, memory, and affect.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the seminar style of the class and I felt that we had a good report, facilitated in large part (or perhaps created) by Professor Wiegman. I always look forward to this class because of our weekly debates and how we get lost into Sedgwick's dense writing. I also really enjoyed going into the archive with members of the class as it transformed what was ordinarily an individual experience into a group one. I liked the individual aspect of curating our own archives of Sedgwick's work and archives.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The archive diaries were super helpful and getting to read one another's gave me both a wider sense of the archive and how many directions even the members of our class could go with the materials available. Reading "Billy Budd" along with Epistemology of the Closet was a highlight for me and I would have gotten a lot out of doing another pairing like that either for another chapter of "Epistemology of the Closet" or for a chapter of "Between Men."

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Focus on singular figure - archival opportunity

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Formally bringing in in non-Sedgwick texts that we ended up being in conversation with anyway, such as Marlon Ross.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Engaging with Sedgwick’s personal archive while reading her published work created a dynamic interplay between theory and material life. It made the abstract feel embodied.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Eve Sedgwick's writing was stimulating in and of itself. I appreciated how engaged my peers were in the conversation every week. Professor Wiegman always had incredible insights and contextualized the moment that Sedgwick was writing in and the debates around various feminist interests. I felt very lucky to have a professor and a group of like-minded peers who added so much to my reading and understanding of Sedgwick's work.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Being able to talk across Sedgwick's published work, the archive, the events she was invited to and involved with, the movements she participated in, etc. enriched the conversations. Often in courses that do literary theory, the 'author dead' (whether or not they are actually dead) so we aren't invested in conversations around what they were reading or who they were talking to at a given moment. But since we were all deep in Sedgwick's papers, it was 'stimulating' (Sedgwick would appreciate that that is the word being used in this question) to be able to bring up in class 'oh that thought is one that came up in X email to Y person and was actually related there to this other idea that isn't in the published work explicitly, Z).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Lot of reading but good overview on Sedgwick

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to love and dislike Sedgwick!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It may be difficult at first (or still at the end), but you will come away from this course thinking differently—not just about theory, but about what it means to study, to remember, and to feel through texts and archives.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it, although I don't know that Professor Wiegman will be teaching it again. There are a lot of readings-- start a couple days before. And enjoy it!!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you anticipate using Sedgwick in your work - this course will be invaluable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I am a MFA student and haven't experience academic study training, so this course is really, super hard for me. But also because of this course, I have to force myself read many English papers in this semester, which really help me to get used to English reading and writing environment I am currently in. Also, reading these papers give me other perspectives to see this world, especially related to topics such as Asian-American and Korean War.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text:
Applying critical scholarly works to current events

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My close reading skills, critical thinking capacity, and knowledge of either colonial or postcolonial theoretical backgrounds were greatly reinforced.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed more intellectual capacity on critical thinking regarding topics of colonialism, neoliberalism, and violence. The instructor provides a good connection between theoretical materials and analysis of specific cases. First of all, I was able to reflect on the epistemological perception of Cold War and the manifestation of its polarization regarding historical narratives. Second, I was able to develop a critical understanding of violence in the context of de-colonization and the limitations of nation-states. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed several valuable ways of thinking and analysis. First, I was introduced to foundational game theories that helped me understand how systems of rules, play, and interaction can be used to critique and reimagine social dynamics. Second, I strengthened my analytical mindset by learning to draw connections between diverse readings, case studies, and media, bringing together theory and practice in meaningful ways during discussion. Finally, I began to see technology not just as a tool but as a medium that shapes how we understand identity and selfhood, especially through immersive experiences like games, virtual realities, and interactive media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Introduction to a massive range of ideas within feminist theory, and the ability to critically discuss the works with humility and curiosity. Also, all of us got to participate in a world-famous conference on feminist theory!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Professor Nash surveyed the many, often conflicting, ways that (Black) feminisms have understood sexuality, gender, the university, law, identity, form, and beauty. Genealogies of feminisms—Professor Nash asks us to attend to the plurality of theoretical feminist frameworks—too often narrate its development through the contributions of white women, eliding the work of Black, third world, and indigenous feminists. Professor Nash corrects this omission.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Knowledge of Black feminism and it’s archives/epistemologies
2. The legal basis and majors legal scholars that underpin a lot of historical and contemporary feminist theory
3. Knowledge of different movements within feminist theory, e.g Standpoint Theory, Transnational Feminism, etc

3. Developing a strong foundation for feminist theory

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned to consider feminist theory broadly, not only through text that have been read and reread over the past few years in the field of WGS.
I learned from the instructor about how to handle a diverse class and sensitive class discussion.
I learned the importance of coming into class with questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Nash is an exemplary pedagogue. She began each seminar by inviting us to each pose a question about the materials at hand, then deftly facilitated our conversation around these inquiries. She insisted we pay attention to the nitty gritty: to the context of the theorizations, to their forms of articulation, and to the unspoken intellectual currents. She challenged us to stay with what we found most challenging rather than deflect or arrive to some facile consensus.

response_text: In this course, I learned more about existentialism and nihilism. Those were concepts I wasn't familiar with coming into the course. I appreciated the opportunity to challenge the traditional existentialist canon that centers white men. As a non-white student this was helpful in getting and keeping me engaged in the course. I was also encouraged to think about the ways other scholars engage with themes from existentialism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that the body and performance must be recognized as a vital source of knowledge production.I developed skills in thinking about and representing my research in different ways: drawing it out, writing about it in a stream-of-consciousness manner, activating a text I am working with through movement, and more.I adopted the thought process that endings are a social construct and sometimes the work comes to a temporary stopping point, but it is always developing whether you work on it or not. I feel more comfortable with the mentality that things will always be unfinished and I can always return to them when inspiration strikes again.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How the body has been ignored and forgotten in much of academic scholarship and how the written word has and still dominates what knowledge is valued (Spatz, Foster, Hartman)
How power is subverted and claimed in ways that the colonial gaze misses or misconstrues  (Mahmood, Taylor)
How scholars, artists, and ourselves are challenging notions of objective, rational fact as truth ~ bringing in creative writing, movement, performance and interdisciplinary thinking into our work

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The text activations were extremely effective in my engagement with each text. The first one we did felt like enough. If we had done two, I think it may have been too much.I was especially engaged with the text activation about the punching, slashing, floating, etc. that Professor Wilbur offered. It was an incredibly useful visual that I return to when thinking about my word choices and each position I take in a paper.I really appreciated the alteration of the classroom setup. It was mentally stimulating to sit in a new spot every day and it helped me get connected to other students in class.The accountability structure for the final project was well-timed for me. I grew more comfortable with sharing work in the development stages, which I feel made my paper stronger.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Functional knowledge and understanding of Feminism, Black Feminism, and Cultural Criticism. 
2) Insight into bell hooks and the collective body of her work and the capacity to critique her work alongside other integral voices. 
3) Experience in an exceptional classroom pedagogically led and formed by Black Feminist thought.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have a deeper understanding of feminist theory and practical engagement with praxis in my daily life; I have learned how to write more concisely; and I have learned how to contextualize authors and material in the times in which they were written.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about black feminist theory from bell hooks perspective.
How to speak intelligently about feminist theory
Writing short critiques of popular culture from a feminist perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- The reasons behind and how to meaningfully provide a cultural critique. 
- A more nuanced approach to engaging with a single author
- A better understanding of Black feminist theory

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed critical thinking skills as it relates to engaging materials. I am able to interrogate texts, films, tv shows, and other forms of cultural production in a way that takes into account the purpose, contemporary context, and historical context. I can offer respectful critique. I also gained a strong understanding of Black feminism as it relates to addressing sexism and navigating the role of imperialist white supremacist capitalist heteropatriarchy in our lives. I also learned how to take seriously the work of a single scholar, leaving space for the ways that their work and thoughts may evolve and change overtime.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1.  i now have a headful of bell hooks! and black feminist theory
2. theory as liberatory practice and it should start from lived experiences and attend to lived realities; critiques of imperialist white-supremacist capitalist patriarchy
3. how to do cultural criticism and contextualize things we are discussing and reading and watching 
4. black feminist fat studies and trans studies
5. what post identarian post intersectionality black feminist theories look like

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) The consistent invitation for discussion and willingness from the Professor to allow time for processing thoughts alongside our peers allowed for significant learning. 
2) The short cultural critiques enabled me to put language to my thoughts upon reading the texts for each class and also kept me accountable for reading the material. I am deeply thankful - in hindsight - for the assignments. 
3) I found the discussant assignments to be particularly productive as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor embodied bell hooks' teaching style and made the classroom environment comfortable, welcoming, and affirming.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Sitting in a circle for class was a great way to facilitate discussions.  I do feel that we did get off-topic in some classes with personal stories but all of the classes were beneficial.  I would like the professor to streamline the amount of reading in the course to be more specific with the topics she would like to discuss in the seminar.  We read a lot of information in a short amount of time but did not really discuss all that we were assigned to read.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:

- Small seminar style was essential for this type of course 
- Integration of various types of media including video interviews and movies 
- Fantastic facilitation

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Lane created a welcoming classroom environment where all students were encourage and willing to participate in class discussions. We had space to agree with one another but also respectfully disagree as we wrestled with the bell hooks' texts. I appreciated the class assingnments as they were non-traditional. I enjoyed getting to reflect on how certain themes have shaped my own life and critically engage with one of my favorite movies. Each class session, Professor Lane or a classmate set us the session by providing important contextual information then asking thought-provoking questions of all of us. Professor Lane made us all feel like our voices matters but also ensured to keep our discussions centered in the text for that week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: i think Professor Lane's pairing of bell hooks's writings with other black feminist theorists' articles was very helpful. i think the things we read were very illuminating and interesting, not just bell hooks but also esp. Ana Quring, Da'Shaun Harrison, Julian Glover, Jen Nash, etc. i think the explanation of what cultural criticism is was very helpful. i like the chance to be discussant and to present our draft and the chance to team up with my classmates to teach Feminism 101

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was immensely stimulating because it required significant critical thinking and there were so few people in the class that it allowed consistent invitation and opportunity to speak. There  were no 'lecture' components and it was discussion oriented, which made it much easier to listen to each other and grow alongside one another.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The weekly reflections demanded critically attention to the material and thoughtful insight. Additionally, there were several in-class exercises that required us to think like feminist scholars teaching others about feminism, which meant that we had to engage with the material on a deeper level to be able to teach it.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The other students provided more stimulating than the information provided by the professor.  We learned from each other, which made the class worthwhile.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Everyone in the classroom seemingly felt at ease to share their thoughts and opinions. I was really intrigued by the types of perspectives that were shared and being able to disagree effectively.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class material, assignments, and questions asked all made the class intellectually stimulating. Professor Lane's assignments invited us to engage with texts in different ways that required utilizing skills and knowledge that we don't always utilize in academia. I felt like I could truly put myself into the class discussions and my class assignments.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: the readings, my classmates, and Professor Lane made this class stimulating

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: An apt cliche is that you will get out what you put in - doing the work and reading the material will result in an exceptional classroom experience. This course material is integral for anyone interested in dismantling oppressive power structures.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Students who enjoy rigorous engagement with feminist scholarship and also like learning in less rigid (i.e., inflexible and restrictive traditional classrooms) environments that foster personal and academic growth would benefit from taking this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course should be labeled writing and reading intensive in its current form.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want to get a deeper understanding of Black feminist theory and diving into the body of work of bell hooks, this is an incredible course. Professor Lane is dynamic and creates a fantastic discussion with a variety of perspectives and opinions. Prepare for a lot of reading, but it's worth it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this course. It was great getting to delve into numerous works by bell hooks and to engage Black feminism in depth. She pushed and challenged us to see things in new ways and provided a classroom environment in which we could be authentic.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: i would absolutely recommend it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: After this course, I feel significantly more capable of approaching critical theory with a thorough methodology for deep engagement. I found our "grid" exercise incredibly useful, as well as navigating key questions, concept clusters, and connections to a genealogy of other feminist lit.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- I am no longer afraid of the academic monograph
- Class treats improve everything
- Look out for aesthetic saviorism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I became a more attentive reader, more confident in sharing my thoughts, and better at asking questions of both the texts we read and my peers in the graduate seminar room to better understand the theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Feminist Studies Now, and Again set out to trace the (dis)continuities between '70s contemporary feminisms. This framework required that I think meta-discursively; this hadn't been my strength, and I leave the course more confident in my ability to do so. Moreover, Professors Nash and Wiegman modeled how to analyze scholarly methodology, in turn developing my ability to identify a text's argument, intervention, style, and archive. These are vital intellectual skills. That said, the professors' own commitments to investigating field formations and transformations occasionally became repetitive by the semester's end and foreclosed other ways of engaging the material.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a range of critical approaches to feminist texts, such as asking after political vision and attachment, genre, and affect, and aesthetic analysis. I learned how to consider such texts metadiscursively and deepened my understanding of field formation. I gained knowledge of a range of canonical and especially contemporary feminist texts that highlighted sustained areas of debate or conversation and critical habits.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Skepticism of the desire for innocence/purity/to be "outside"; variety and impact of possible forms (e.g., manifesto, academic article or book, play, memoir, etc.); connections between/among past and present

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated that Robyn and Jen started out each class with an introduction to the authors, context for the text, and their own key questions to facilitate discussion. I also appreciated their contributions to our own discussions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The grid, obviously. (In all seriousness, I really appreciated the way Jen and Robyn prepped for class and facilitated discussion.)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciate that we could write a critical engagement with a colleague. This flexibility meant I could dig deeper into a text with someone else before coming to class. Participating in the collaborative exercise before discussing the text in class gave me an extra layer of understanding and helped me develop new questions for the larger seminar conversation. It also mitigated what usually happens in class when people feign understanding because, in the initial conversation, we could be more honest about our engagement with the text and help each other fill in the gaps.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professors Nash and Wiegman began each session by noting the concepts and questions to be considered, which helped structure the discussions. Moreover, the professors' knowledge of and excitement for the materials energized the classroom.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the conversation-based seminar format and would keep the practice of mapping terms/inquiries/etc. I appreciated when one or both professors gave more background/context for particular text(s) in certain classes and would make this more of a convention across classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Instructors' openness and trust in students made class discussions rigorous and thought-provoking

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The thread between each week's texts was incredibly stimulating; each week built off of the previous week so well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The atmosphere of engagement and discussion was stimulating. Both students and professors seemed genuinely interested in what everyone else was thinking, and folks were tuned in to one another, making it easy to tell when someone was thinking, when to invite someone in, etc.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The wide variety of readings made the course stimulating. Although sometimes tedious, submitting the critical engagement throughout the semester and receiving incredibly generous and attentive feedback from the professors meant that I could see myself developing in both my writing and engagement.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Again, I appreciate the course's ambition to think about the development of feminist thought from the Second Wave to the present. This ambition, though, was unrealized. The syllabus did not seem to have a sense of direction, the selection of materials thus felt arbitrary—little justification was offered for the bibliography, and some texts were assigned that the professors hadn't read—, the readings were frequently redundant—and insufficiently representative of contemporary feminist intellectual production. The most convincing unit was "American Grammar," in which we traced the rearticulations of Hortense Spillers's seminal "Mama's Baby, Papa's Maybe" across several monographs.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Active conversation made this class stimulating as well as the topic. Dedicated courses like this in feminist studies are important to thinking through history and the challenges of the present, and this course brought together students from multiple disciplines. Though I understand this is not a foundations course, I would have benefitted from the inclusion of more canonical texts. For instance, the American Grammar section was one of the most stimulating, largely owing to the richness of Mama's Baby, Papa's Maybe and its influence on many other texts.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The students made class discussion particularly stimulating, especially the variety of backgrounds/trainings/knowledge bases and the students' willingness and ability to work hard, ask questions, and think critically

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was the most intellectually rigorous seminar I have taken at Duke, as each week required such deep engagement with each text in order to make the most out of each seminar. It was incredibly rewarding. I am a better scholar for this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Jen and Robyn will challenge you, and you will become a more expansive thinker if you take the readings and conversations seriously. The class is rigorous but not difficult, and by that I mean it will take a lot of time to get through the readings and come to class ready to participate actively. Take it seriously and you will get a lot out of it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is befit for students who research feminist intellectual history. Those who approach feminism with other aims may find its focus on the circulation of feminist discourse limiting. I nevertheless appreciate that Duke offers classes like this, and I encourage the University to continue to support advanced feminist inquiry.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I wholeheartedly recommend taking an advanced, contemporary-forward feminist studies course like this for students from any discipline interested in women's studies, gender and sexuality studies, queer and trans studies, and critical race studies.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It will be a lot of work, and it will be worth it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I became a more attentive reader, more confident in sharing my thoughts, and better at asking questions of both the texts we read and my peers in the graduate seminar room to better understand the theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Feminist Studies Now, and Again set out to trace the (dis)continuities between '70s contemporary feminisms. This framework required that I think meta-discursively; this hadn't been my strength, and I leave the course more confident in my ability to do so. Moreover, Professors Nash and Wiegman modeled how to analyze scholarly methodology, in turn developing my ability to identify a text's argument, intervention, style, and archive. These are vital intellectual skills. That said, the professors' own commitments to investigating field formations and transformations occasionally became repetitive by the semester's end and foreclosed other ways of engaging the material.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a range of critical approaches to feminist texts, such as asking after political vision and attachment, genre, and affect, and aesthetic analysis. I learned how to consider such texts metadiscursively and deepened my understanding of field formation. I gained knowledge of a range of canonical and especially contemporary feminist texts that highlighted sustained areas of debate or conversation and critical habits.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Skepticism of the desire for innocence/purity/to be "outside"; variety and impact of possible forms (e.g., manifesto, academic article or book, play, memoir, etc.); connections between/among past and present

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated that Robyn and Jen started out each class with an introduction to the authors, context for the text, and their own key questions to facilitate discussion. I also appreciated their contributions to our own discussions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The grid, obviously. (In all seriousness, I really appreciated the way Jen and Robyn prepped for class and facilitated discussion.)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciate that we could write a critical engagement with a colleague. This flexibility meant I could dig deeper into a text with someone else before coming to class. Participating in the collaborative exercise before discussing the text in class gave me an extra layer of understanding and helped me develop new questions for the larger seminar conversation. It also mitigated what usually happens in class when people feign understanding because, in the initial conversation, we could be more honest about our engagement with the text and help each other fill in the gaps.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professors Nash and Wiegman began each session by noting the concepts and questions to be considered, which helped structure the discussions. Moreover, the professors' knowledge of and excitement for the materials energized the classroom.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the conversation-based seminar format and would keep the practice of mapping terms/inquiries/etc. I appreciated when one or both professors gave more background/context for particular text(s) in certain classes and would make this more of a convention across classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Instructors' openness and trust in students made class discussions rigorous and thought-provoking

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The thread between each week's texts was incredibly stimulating; each week built off of the previous week so well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The atmosphere of engagement and discussion was stimulating. Both students and professors seemed genuinely interested in what everyone else was thinking, and folks were tuned in to one another, making it easy to tell when someone was thinking, when to invite someone in, etc.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The wide variety of readings made the course stimulating. Although sometimes tedious, submitting the critical engagement throughout the semester and receiving incredibly generous and attentive feedback from the professors meant that I could see myself developing in both my writing and engagement.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Again, I appreciate the course's ambition to think about the development of feminist thought from the Second Wave to the present. This ambition, though, was unrealized. The syllabus did not seem to have a sense of direction, the selection of materials thus felt arbitrary—little justification was offered for the bibliography, and some texts were assigned that the professors hadn't read—, the readings were frequently redundant—and insufficiently representative of contemporary feminist intellectual production. The most convincing unit was "American Grammar," in which we traced the rearticulations of Hortense Spillers's seminal "Mama's Baby, Papa's Maybe" across several monographs.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Active conversation made this class stimulating as well as the topic. Dedicated courses like this in feminist studies are important to thinking through history and the challenges of the present, and this course brought together students from multiple disciplines. Though I understand this is not a foundations course, I would have benefitted from the inclusion of more canonical texts. For instance, the American Grammar section was one of the most stimulating, largely owing to the richness of Mama's Baby, Papa's Maybe and its influence on many other texts.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The students made class discussion particularly stimulating, especially the variety of backgrounds/trainings/knowledge bases and the students' willingness and ability to work hard, ask questions, and think critically

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was the most intellectually rigorous seminar I have taken at Duke, as each week required such deep engagement with each text in order to make the most out of each seminar. It was incredibly rewarding. I am a better scholar for this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Jen and Robyn will challenge you, and you will become a more expansive thinker if you take the readings and conversations seriously. The class is rigorous but not difficult, and by that I mean it will take a lot of time to get through the readings and come to class ready to participate actively. Take it seriously and you will get a lot out of it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is befit for students who research feminist intellectual history. Those who approach feminism with other aims may find its focus on the circulation of feminist discourse limiting. I nevertheless appreciate that Duke offers classes like this, and I encourage the University to continue to support advanced feminist inquiry.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I wholeheartedly recommend taking an advanced, contemporary-forward feminist studies course like this for students from any discipline interested in women's studies, gender and sexuality studies, queer and trans studies, and critical race studies.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It will be a lot of work, and it will be worth it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I completely changed my reading style throughout this course.  We had to tackle a lot of challenging texts, but I think the order in which we completed them made sense because we had to use the concepts as perspectives for future readings.  It was an interesting anthropological course, something I was not used to, we did not do a lot of field work and creating our own ethnographic work, nor did we solely read ethnographic material.  I did not expect this, but I have started to apply the tools we learned in this class on reading and discussing as well as the key concepts and developing ideas in other courses.  In summary, I learned how to go through readings differently and apply new perspectives for future readings as well as connect these to other readings with my own concept I create such as we did in the papers and finally talk through and relearn a reading in a way I did not originally do such as we did in Winart.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about proper ways to annotate reading, and how to read scholarly sources in general.  I also learned how to write an anthropology paper, I had never written a true college paper let alone anthropology paper so I learned the format of how to write that but also learned the differences between high school and college writing. I also learned so much through the course through discussion, we talked all the time and it was so helpful as it developed my understanding and knowledge of the reading but also the concepts within.

response_text: This course is not just for pre-meds or sociology majors - this class is a wonderful and interesting way to explore society, labor, and current events through many different lenses, while building very important academic skills. It is not difficult, and only requires a few out of class assignments. The majority of work is done via a very open discussion in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class has only a few essays throughout the semester, but readings are due almost every class. Readings are graded based on three annotations which you do on the assigned reading. The annotations are pretty easy just 3-5 sentences per. The final assignment is a podcast which is pretty easy as well you work in groups and it takes a few hours to complete.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The readings are much longer and more complex and will take longer than expected. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read a lot, and know that you will not understand everything-- but you will learn so much: in addition to the concepts, you'll learn just how to read effectively and what to pull from articles and how to make sense of works within historical context. cool guest speaker opportunities, meaningful assignments. This class taught me more about how to be a better writer than w101 ever did. If you have any interest at all in healthcare then this class is worth taking, and the prof is extremely smart (can be initially hard to follow, but cares a lot about us understanding and always takes time to cool it down and explain)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

The course changed me as a student and I am so proud of the differences I have made as a learner.  It is excellent as a shift from high school to college work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about different feminist scientists in the field such as Donna Harraway, Sandra Harding, and Emily Martin. I also learned about the vast disadvantage/discrimination that women face in the field of medicine as patients and as practitioners. I also learned about different ways of thinking and different knowledge's that help to explore more truths in the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about examining how biases infected science and affected how things were perceived, especially for women. I also learned how, due to androcentrism, this manifested into thinking that women were strange and attempting to understand them. I also learned more about history that is not traditionally taught in schools, such as the fact that the field of gynecology was able to progress due to the medical torture of Black enslaved women.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Namakkal created a strong learning environment overall. She is genuinely one of the most knowledgeable professors I’ve ever had—she seems to have deep insight into every part of the world. Her lectures were intellectually engaging, and she had a great ability to connect themes across time and space, which made the material more meaningful. However, the structure of the lectures was sometimes confusing. We had two lectures a week and one discussion, but many of the lectures felt more like unstructured conversations where students were asked to share personal opinions/views on topics. I often got lost in the material because I prefer more structured lectures where the professor speaks and explains key ideas clearly, followed by space for questions. The discussions should be the space for student participation, not the lectures. In fact, one of the most effective classes was when we had a guest speaker who delivered a full lecture without turning it into a discussion—I found that format much easier to follow and more informative.Professor Gasparowicz is a very sweet and kind professor, and she was also my discussion leader. However, her lectures were often difficult to follow. She seemed unprepared at times and made factual mistakes that Professor Namakkal had to correct. Her slides mostly consisted of long quotes that we had to read aloud and then discuss with a partner, which didn’t feel like real teaching. Unfortunately, I don’t remember much from her lectures, even though I believe she is knowledgeable. That said, she was more effective as a discussion leader, and I felt more engaged in our smaller discussion group than during her lectures. It honestly breaks my heart to write this and be a little harsh, because she is such a kind person—but I also have high expectations from Duke professors, and unfortunately, my expectations weren’t fulfilled in her lectures. In terms of grading, she was also the one evaluating my reading responses, and that was another area of difficulty. Her feedback was often vague and filled with grammar mistakes, which made it hard to understand what she actually wanted from me. Even by the end of the semester, I didn’t know what the grading criteria were and every new grade was a complete surprise. Comments like “explain” or “how?” weren’t helpful—especially for a freshman still learning how to write in college. With a strict 250-word limit, it’s hard to know what “explain” means when space is so limited. When I compared feedback with other students in different discussion groups, I noticed the grading was very inconsistent. It felt extremely subjective, which made the whole process more frustrating than helpful. Clearer rubrics and more objective, consistent grading across TAs would definitely improve the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
I loved how we looked past the surface level of many different topics. Like looking SAP in Jamaica, or developing an idea of modern day imperialism, and dismantling development theory, which many developed nations use to justify their actions. We were able to see past the arguments of politicians in power that use the surface level argument. 
Sometimes the guest speakers were a bit boring and not easy to keep up with. 
The reading responses were also hard to get a hang of. I would have appreciated an example of a good reading response from the beginning, I think it would have allowed me to do better on my first couple of reading responses. 
Although the midterm was a lot to study for, it definitely felt easier than the reading responses, as I generally like to explain a lot, so it is a good balance for people who may be used to writing a lot compared to the reading responses which were more difficult for me.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is very different from what you might expect. If you're hoping to focus on current global issues, you may find the emphasis on colonialism throughout the semester limiting. The main component of the class is writing—especially the weekly reading responses—which can be challenging and is graded strictly. While the course is officially about global issues, in practice it felt more like a writing class with a cross-cultural inquiry tag. That said, it’s a valuable experience for improving your writing and learning to engage critically with texts. Just be prepared for the writing component to take center stage.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is hard for an intro course but take it anyways. One of the best classes I have taken at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course content was exceptionally well-curated, focusing on topics and readings that were both relevant and significant. One area that particularly stood out to me was the exploration of the rise of Western civilization and the socio-historical forces behind it. This topic prompted deep reflection and encouraged me to adopt a more deliberate and nuanced perspective. While I had previously considered these issues, engaging with this reading compelled me to approach topics with greater intentionality. I now find myself drawn towards conducting higher contextual examinations, delving not only into immediate considerations but also the deeper historical factors that shape contemporary events.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: There was a large amount of reading in this class, most of which were very information-heavy, densely worded, and abstract concepts that take a considerable amount of time to read, and even more to understand. That being said, I definitely learned how to read lengthy texts and vastly different narrative/literature styles more efficiently, which is a useful skill for all of my courses at Duke to come. I also learned how to think more critically about texts -- I might not have understood everything that was taught to the fullest extent, but critiquing it, I have learned, is a fundamental start towards understanding it. Lastly, learning how to write succinctly but powerfully was also a challenging and very valuable part of the course. Many of our writing assignments had hard word limits, which is difficult to implement when you're reading many of these philosophical-style texts that are so information-dense, but I definitely had to force myself to see which parts of my writing were necessary and which parts were not, and how to word/arrange their content more eloquently and succinctly.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to think critically about the global systems that are engrained in our everyday lives. I learned how to summarize and analyze texts concisely and connect themes throughout the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Everything possible. Understanding the world and the theorists behind them has been incredibly stimulating.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: ICS has taught me how to try and avoid having an Orientalist view on matters, how to write in a concise yet impactful way, and how to critically analyze global issues with cultural sensitivity and a broader perspective.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that our Western mindset is extremely flawed and one-sided, and that it takes lots of work and knowledge to even grasp overcoming the biases we naturally hold. I learned that definitions of common words like Modernity or Globalization have many different meanings held by different individuals, and that no true "correct" definition can be established. I developed skills of skepticism and discussion about uncomfortable topics and about the unknown relationships in our world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Orientalism and its effects on the perception of "The Orient" by Western cultures. I also learned about the core-periphery model and how it functions by positioning the core (Western) countries in a state of political and economic power over the periphery (third-world) countries. Lastly, we learned about the clear overlap between colonialism and pollution, and how potential eco-conscious solutions can have devastating effects on indigenous groups.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I LOVED ICS195! Not only was the content extremely interesting, it was also intellectually engaging at all times because of the topics we covered are not often thought of as the mainstream ideologies people are exposed to in their everyday lives. Needless to say, I found myself questioning the most foundational beliefs I have held for most of my life and while it was disorienting at times, especially because of the unconventional dialogue we worked with, the support of the instructors at office hours, particularly Professor Mathers and Melissa Karp, made understanding, reconciling with, and applying those difficult conversations much more manageable and understandable. I significantly appreciate the instructors' willingness to challenge our thinking, and not just agree with everything we said, and their efforts in fostering constructive and critical conversations.
